text:
Read the full ranking here:
https://t.co/Rwgcp60K44

I’m excited to see @utrgv earn national recognition from @usnews. For the first time in its 10 year history, the university has been named one of the Most Innovative Schools in the country, an honor shared by only 66 universities nationwide.

UTRGV is also ranked No. 1 in Texas among public universities for social mobility and lowest student borrowing, showing how higher education can open doors and change lives for South Texans. Every student deserves the resources and support to reach their full potential, and I remain committed to securing the federal investments that make that possible.

Congratulations to the students, faculty, and staff whose hard work made this achievement happen!
Read the full letter here: https://t.co/3jX9BF6XCP

"No one in America should fear for their safety for sharing their beliefs."

Today, I joined with my colleagues in the @ProbSolveCaucus to make it clear: political violence and threats have no place in our country. We can disagree without demeaning each other, and our debates should reflect respect, not fear or intimidation. Every citizen deserves to speak and participate in democracy without threat of harm.

We're committed to upholding the dignity of every American and building a political culture where differences are addressed through dialogue, not violence. By standing together, we can strengthen our democracy through respectful engagement, even when we disagree.

Thank you to co-chairs @RepTomSuozzi and @RepBrianFitz for their leadership in promoting bipartisanship and bringing Americans together.

I was deeply saddened by the passing of Judge Oscar Martinez on Saturday, a Laredo native whose decades of service left a lasting mark on our community. From his early years of military service in the United States Air Force to his long tenure on the Webb County Commissioners’ Court as Justice of the Peace, Judge Martinez dedicated himself to public service with integrity and purpose.

Beyond the courtroom, Judge Martinez was a successful entrepreneur and a committed community leader. As President of LULAC Council 12 and through his work with local schools, he championed opportunity, justice, and programs that gave young people the tools to succeed. His efforts strengthened both civic life and educational opportunities across South Texas.

In every sense, Judge Martinez lived out his faith and commitment to others. His legacy of service will continue to inspire future generations in Laredo and beyond. My deepest condolences are with the Martinez family as we celebrate his remarkable life.

#OnceATigerAlwaysATiger

I was honored to present a congressional recognition to Erineo Chabera for his dedicated service during the Vietnam War. I was also pleased to be joined by Former Pct. 4 County Commissioner Tommy Atkinson and Mr. Chabera’s family members for this special occasion at his home. His courage, resilience, and sacrifice reflect the strength of our veterans and remind us of the deep gratitude our nation owes to those who answered the call.

Over the weekend I also attended the Diez y Seis de Septiembre Charreada in San Antonio, a proud tradition showcasing Mexican culture through roping, horsemanship, and community celebration. Thank you to the San Antonio Charro Association for keeping this rich heritage alive! https://t.co/aHvfQdqoMA

Solutions unite us, and we need to make sure that we bring down and tone down the rhetoric on both sides.

I spoke with @FrankMcCaffrey1 of @cbs4rgv about the rise in political violence and why it's critical that we lower the temperature in our national dialogue. By encouraging constructive solutions and civil discourse, public leaders strengthen our communities – a principle that guides how I serve in Congress.

Watch the segment here:

This weekend in Universal City, I joined veterans, military families, community partners, and local leaders to celebrate the 50th anniversary of American Legion Post 667. For half a century, Post 667 has been a pillar of honor, service, and fellowship, providing veterans with support, strengthening families, and instilling the values of duty and patriotism in future generations.

As your U.S. Representative, I remain committed to ensuring our veterans receive the care and resources they deserve. I was proud to cosponsor the PACT Act, now law, which expands healthcare benefits for veterans exposed to toxic substances. I also supported the Disabled Veterans Housing Support Act, which passed in the House, to ensure disabled veterans are not unfairly disqualified from housing assistance. This year’s appropriations bill includes billions for veterans programs, from housing and childcare to mental health services and support for homeless veterans.

I want to thank American Legion Post 667 for 50 years of sacrifice, fellowship, and devotion to community. Congratulations on this historic milestone, and may the next 50 years continue to bring strength, service, and unity to Universal City and beyond. 🇺🇸

Read more from @WashPost.👇
https://t.co/Mb539bdZTA

Families in South Texas, and across the entire country, are feeling the squeeze as housing, groceries, and utilities climb – leaving less and less at the end of each month. Far too many are forced to dip into savings or take on debt just to cover basic needs.

I remain committed to lowering costs, protecting Medicaid, Medicare, and SNAP, and ensuring hardworking people have the support they need to get ahead. We must keep building an economy that works for everyone, not just the wealthiest few.

After today’s votes, I had the chance to celebrate my birthday in the office with my daughter Christina and my team. Christina made the day extra special by bringing delicious food and cake – thank you for making it such a memorable celebration!

I’m grateful I could mark the day with my family and staff who help me serve #TX28 every day. Now it’s back home to Laredo for another district work week!🇺🇸

This week, my staffer Zachary Johnson spoke at the seventh annual Congressional Hackathon. This event is an opportunity for Congress to interface with the latest advances in technology and productivity.

It’s crucial that Congressional staff are at the cutting edge of modernization so we can best represent constituents.

This week, I joined my colleagues in the @ProbSolveCaucus, a bipartisan group dedicated to respectful debate and finding common ground, to stand together in unity and sing God Bless America. 

We stood not as Democrats or Republicans, but as Americans concerned about the rise in divisive and inflammatory political rhetoric. Violence has no place in this country, and I'm determined to work across the aisle to deliver solutions and bring the temperature down.

Thank you to co-chairs @RepBrianFitz and @RepTomSuozzi for their continued leadership in bringing members of both parties together.
Read more from @TexasTribune.⬇️ https://t.co/cziKIPXEBm

In South Texas communities like Starr, Hidalgo, and Webb counties, our hospitals and clinics are stretched to the limit. From Rio Grande City to Laredo, doctors and nurses are already working under immense pressure to keep their doors open and families healthy.

After partisan cuts to Medicaid and the looming expiration of health insurance tax credits, the situation is set to become even worse. If Congress fails to act, more than 113,000 people in #TX28 will face higher monthly premiums – making insurance unaffordable altogether for many families.

At @GCHCTexas in Laredo, providers are doing everything they can to avoid cutting staff or reducing services, but the expiration of the tax credits would move the situation from crisis to catastrophe. That means longer ER wait times, fewer staff at clinics, and the real possibility of rural hospitals being forced to scale back or close.

This is unacceptable. I voted against the budget that defunded Medicaid, and I’ll keep fighting to protect it, extend tax credits, and ensure every family in South Texas can access affordable, quality health care.

Yesterday, I met with representatives from @Toyota and their supplier, @YazakiNA, to discuss how unpredictable tariffs are hurting automotive manufacturing, jobs, and our economy.

Having played a critical role in negotiating the USMCA, the trade deal signed into law by President Trump, I know firsthand how important certainty and stability in foreign trade are for businesses and workers alike. That agreement gave manufacturers the confidence to invest, expand, and create jobs across #TX28 and beyond.

Business leaders are once again calling for that same stability, making clear that harmful tariffs undermine growth and put American jobs at risk. In Congress, I'll keep working across the aisle to ensure South Texans have a fair, reliable, and competitive trade environment.

Today, I met with @mhmstx, a faith-based organization dedicated to serving families and strengthening communities across our region. We discussed how my office can support their mission of expanding access to health care, improving food security, and addressing other essential needs so South Texas can continue to grow.

In Congress, I'm working to ensure that every family, no matter where they live, has the resources and opportunities they need to succeed. That means advancing policies that invest in healthier communities, stronger infrastructure, and a brighter future for South Texas.

Read more from @KeepAmCovered.
https://t.co/Kj5lnDlgCA

With vital health insurance tax credits under threat, monthly premiums for 113,000 people in #TX28 are set to skyrocket. The program serves everyone from small business owners to rural communities, and allowing it to expire could result in complete loss of coverage.

This tax credit makes affordable, quality health care possible for every South Texan. I’ll keep working with my colleagues in Congress to protect it and ensure families across our district can get the care they need without jeopardizing their financial security.

This afternoon, I met with representatives from the Southeast Lumber Manufacturers Association, including Chris and Emily deMilliano of the Texas-based company Steely Lumber, to discuss ways to expand opportunities for American lumber producers and workers.

Across #TX28, the lumber industry supports everything from military construction to manufacturing jobs, and I'm committed to keeping their sector strong.  As we shape future economic policy, I’ll continue working to ensure trade agreements prioritize South Texan consumers, businesses, and jobs, while leveling the playing field for domestic industries to compete and thrive internationally.

Today, we recognize Constitution Day, commemorating the signing of the U.S. Constitution on September 17, 1787. This foundational document continues to guide our nation’s principles of democracy and justice, protecting the rights and freedoms we enjoy every day. 

It’s a reminder of the vision and dedication of those who came before us and the responsibility we all share to uphold these values.

This morning, I met with Ruben Garibay, CEO of the @PuertoVerdeGTB, to discuss the proposed Puerto Verde Trade Corridor and how Congress can support South Texan communities that depend on cross-border trade. The project would streamline the flow of goods between Eagle Pass and Piedras Negras to help commerce move more efficiently, create good-paying jobs, and bring costs down for families.

As South Texas continues to grow as a hub for markets and logistics, I’ll keep fighting for free trade, strong and modernized points of entry, and projects that boost our economy while keeping our communities secure.

Today I met with Irene Ramos, a representative of @COABEHQ, Vice President of the Texas Association for Literacy and Adult Education, and #TX28 constituent, to discuss the importance of expanding adult education in Texas. Federal investments in these programs help open doors to opportunity through workforce training, English language acquisition, and other vital skills that strengthen communities in South Texas.

In Congress, I'm committed to supporting education, which is why I introduced an amendment during last week's Appropriations markup to expand access and protect funding for adult learning programs. I’ll keep fighting to ensure every South Texan has the chance to learn, grow, and succeed, regardless of their age.
Watch our full conversation here.⬇️ https://t.co/Eq0IHr9FLd

Last night, I joined @LelandVittert on @NewsNation alongside Richard Goodstein to discuss the future of the Democratic Party.

In such a divisive moment for our country, it’s clear our path forward will only come from the middle – by focusing squarely on the issues that matter most to Americans.

Families are struggling with the cost of living, and our priority must be practical, bipartisan solutions that make life more affordable, from lowering health care costs to supporting small businesses and ensuring safe communities.

This morning, I was welcomed by a panel at the @CHCI Leadership Conference to speak on the critical role Hispanics play in shaping America’s energy future. As our energy needs grow, every community deserves a seat at the table in shaping policies that drive innovation, growth, and opportunity.

Energy is about people and communities, whether it’s a grandmother in Laredo keeping her home cool, a student in San Antonio powering their laptop to pursue a college degree, or the welders and truck drivers supporting our industries. Energy enables us all to live full and productive lives.

As new technologies increase energy demand on the grid, oil and gas remain the foundation for fueling tomorrow's solutions. Hispanic workers, from engineers to entrepreneurs, must be included in building a clean energy future for everyone.

This morning, I met with Air Force veteran Jimmy Cornelius and representatives of @NAFISschools to discuss the importance of funding the Impact Aid program, which provides over $100 million every year to Texan schools alone. This program helps offset the tax revenue that school districts on federal land lose – especially those serving military families like @FSHISD. With these funds, districts can pay teachers, purchase classroom materials, upgrade facilities, and address the unique needs of students with disabilities.

Following our discussion, I had the honor of presenting Jimmy with my congressional challenge coin in recognition of his service to our country and his commitment to expanding educational opportunities.

As a member of the Congressional Impact Aid Caucus, I'm dedicated to securing the resources students need to receive a quality education, no matter where their school is located.

I’m deeply saddened to hear of the passing of Robert Redford. Through iconic performances in Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, The Sting, All the President’s Men, The Natural – among many others – and through his groundbreaking work behind the camera, he shaped American art and cinema for decades. His artistry and fearlessness in storytelling inspired generations of filmmakers and audiences alike.

To his wife, his children, grandchildren, and all who loved him: you are in our thoughts and prayers in this difficult time. He’ll be forever remembered as a giant of Hollywood, a master of his craft, and “the best there ever was.”

This afternoon, my Chief of Staff, Patrick O'Connor, and I met with Pete Arguello, Senior Director of Governmental Relations for @UTHealthSA and a former member of my staff. We discussed expanding access to quality health care, supporting medical research, and strengthening the education system for future health professionals. It was a productive conversation regarding the importance of federal investment in science and medicine, and a great opportunity to catch up with Pete!

Seniors deserve access to early and comprehensive cancer screenings. That’s why I cosponsored the bipartisan Nancy Gardner Sewell Act to expand Medicare coverage for multi-cancer early detection tests.

This bill creates a clear path for @US_FDA-approved tests that can detect multiple cancers early – saving lives, improving outcomes, and lowering costs.

Cancer touches every family. I’ll keep working across the aisle to make sure seniors in South Texas and across the country have access to lifesaving innovations in cancer detection.
Read more from @NPR.⬇️ https://t.co/JpDR8g8krp

Costs are rising across the board for families and businesses. Grocery bills and gas prices keep going up, and everyday essentials are getting more expensive by the week. From food to fuel, these hikes hit working families the hardest and grind the economy to a halt.

Tariffs on basic items like produce and clothing make the problem worse, driving prices higher, slowing economic growth, and leaving Americans to shoulder the burden. In Washington, I'll keep working across the aisle for fair trade policies that lower costs for South Texans, strengthen our economy, and help families get ahead instead of holding them down.
https://t.co/o0aJVAF71h

It was great to meet and thank nearly a dozen members of the Mississippi National Guard stationed in Washington, D.C.’s Navy Yard neighborhood this morning. I’m impressed by their service, dedication, and hard work in keeping our streets safe and secure. It was a sincere honor to offer and share coffee together and to express my appreciation for all that they do.🇺🇸

Happy #NationalHispanicHeritageMonth 

From September 15 to October 15, we celebrate the vibrant cultures and lasting contributions of Hispanic Americans. This month is a time to honor the rich traditions, achievements, and stories that continue to shape and strengthen our communities.
Read more from @TALK1370: https://t.co/Z1MAcxbJWB

I want to thank my classmate and very good friend @RepMcCaul, former Chairman of the Foreign Affairs and Homeland Security Committees, as he prepares to conclude his service in the House of Representatives.

For more than two decades, he's dedicated his career to serving Texas and our nation with distinction. His leadership and commitment have left a lasting mark on the House and on U.S. foreign and homeland security policy.

While his voice will be missed in the chamber, I look forward to seeing his work in the years ahead.

Read more from @business:
https://t.co/bvhvgnYgjg

The latest numbers confirm what many of us have long warned: tariffs are not a solution to our fiscal challenges.

Despite record collections, it barely makes a dent in the nation’s growing budget gap. At the same time, the added cost of imported goods is passed along to consumers, acting as an invisible tax. Families feel it every time they pay more for groceries, clothes for their children, or other everyday essentials. Businesses face the same burden, absorbing higher prices for the materials they need to operate, which slows investment and growth.

South Texans need real solutions that strengthen our economy, manage federal spending responsibly, and lower costs. I’ll continue to support policies that help families get ahead and ensure that hard-working families can build a secure future.
Read more at @politico.⬇️ https://t.co/rFrAtvQtX9

Inflation rose again in August while the job market weakened - that’s bad news for families already struggling with higher prices. Tariffs are raising costs on goods, and South Texans feel it every time they buy groceries, pay the electric bill, or fill up their car.

I’ll keep fighting in Congress to lower the cost of living and deliver relief for our communities and our families.
Learn more from the @newrepublic.⬇️ https://t.co/7wQcDsC8wt

In August alone, the federal government spent $689 billion while bringing in just $344 billion – leaving a $345 billion deficit. Differences like that don’t just stay in Washington. Mounting debt fuels higher borrowing costs, weakens confidence in our economy, and ultimately drives up prices.

This year’s deficit is already the third-highest on record – only topped during the COVID-19 pandemic, when revenues collapsed and Congress passed much-needed emergency relief.

We balanced the budget before under President Clinton, and we can do it again. Reducing the national debt, ensuring transparency and accountability in how federal dollars are spent, and making fiscal discipline a top priority are the only ways to keep the economy strong and growing.
https://t.co/N9n2Rv0fKg

On Wednesday, a shooter entered a high school in Colorado and wounded two children. As a father, my heart aches for the young people harmed by this senseless act of violence and for every parent who fears for their kids in environments that should always be safe.

The tragedies of this week are painful testaments that violence has no place in the United States. As we come together to recover and reflect, we must never stop working toward a safer future for our country.

May God watch over everyone impacted, and may God bless America.

In July, devastating floods swept through the Texas Hill Country, claiming the lives of 135 people and injuring many more.

To help prevent tragedies like this in the future, I secured language directing @NOAA to upgrade early warning systems for severe weather and improve real-time flood detection, with a focus on rural communities. When disaster strikes, every second matters. This amendment will give families more time to prepare, respond, and protect their loved ones.

Let me be clear: I'm doing everything I can in Congress to ensure every community is prepared for severe weather events like the Hill Country flooding. Thank you to Chairman @RepHalRogers and Ranking Member @RepGraceMeng for supporting this commonsense measure that will save lives across the country.

Today, I was appointed to serve once more on Congress’s Appropriations Conference Committee – the first convened since 2019.

In 2019, I served on the Homeland Security Appropriations Conference Committee, where I secured key investments to strengthen security along the Southern border.

Conference Committees bring members of the House and Senate together to reconcile differences in funding bills and deliver one final version that can be signed into law.

This year, I will help negotiate final bills for Military Construction & Veterans Affairs, Agriculture, and the Legislative Branch. I’ll work to ensure these bills support our farmers and ranchers, provide for our veterans and servicemembers, invest in infrastructure, lower costs for families, and reflect the priorities of South Texans.

It’s an honor to represent #TX28 and I look forward to delivering results for our communities.

Yesterday, I met with the @NCBFAA, along with representatives of American, Mexican, and Canadian industries. We had a constructive conversation on the importance of free trade, the need to reduce tariffs, and how these steps can help lower prices for businesses and consumers across the region.

We also explored opportunities to modernize and expand land ports of entry at the Canadian and Mexican borders, especially those in #TX28. Upgrading these facilities will keep goods moving efficiently while equipping @CBP agents with the resources they need to enhance security and safeguard our communities.

In Congress, I'm working to advance policies that lower costs for families, support small businesses, and build an economy that works for both South Texas families and industries.

Great to welcome my friend, and one of South Texas’s outstanding pilots, Remy Salinas, to my office during this busy appropriations season. During our visit, I was able to show him a behind-the-scenes look at the appropriations markup process while he was visiting in Washington.

It’s always great to see friendly faces from back home!

Today, we take a moment to reflect on September 11, 2001.
 
We remember those we lost, honor the service of first responders, and recognize the strength of communities who came together in support of one another. 

May we always carry their memory with us. https://t.co/PmtAuFu4eH

During yesterday's Appropriations Committee markup, I secured my amendment ensuring that funds Congress has appropriated for Hispanic Serving Institutions and the Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs (GEAR UP) grant are not delayed. These programs support students from middle school through high school, opening doors to higher education for kids who might not otherwise have the opportunity. My amendment protects these critical funds from further bureaucratic delays.

Thank you to Chairman @TomColeOK04, Chairman @Robert_Aderholt, and Ranking Member @rosadelauro for their bipartisan support on my amendment, and I look forward to continuing our work to secure funding for higher education programs and grants.

In #TX28, I’ve heard from parents and grandparents who work tirelessly to support their families and want nothing more than the chance to keep learning so they can provide more for them. That's why I offered my amendment during last night's Appropriations Committee markup for expanding opportunities for adults to continue their education.

At every stage of life, education creates pathways to better jobs, a skilled workforce, and brighter futures. From English as a second language to workforce upskilling programs, investing in adult education is an investment in growing communities and a thriving economy, ensuring that the benefits of learning go beyond the classroom.

I’ll keep working with colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure every American has the opportunity to pursue a better life, no matter their age.

At last night’s Appropriations Committee markup, I secured critical language in the bill manager’s amendment to protect the @USDOL Job Corps program from defunding and closure. I've seen firsthand how this program has changed lives in Laredo by giving young people the skills, training, and opportunities they need to succeed, and I'm committed to continuing to support the program.

Job Corps not only helps students set their lives on the path to success, it also strengthens our workforce and supports local communities. I'm looking forward to working with Chairman @TomColeOK04, Chairman @Robert_Aderholt, and Ranking Member @rosadelauro to ensure strong funding for this crucial program.

During the Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Bill markup, I introduced an amendment to ensure federal agencies deliver real results for the American people. 

My amendment strengthens oversight, modernizes the metrics agencies use to evaluate themselves, and ties performance to clear, measurable outcomes. By focusing on results, we can cut duplicative rules and regulations, reduce costs, and remove unnecessary red tape. This ensures agencies stay transparent, operate efficiently, and make the best use of taxpayer resources. 

I’ll keep working with colleagues from both parties to find common ground and prioritize solutions over politics.

I condemn political violence and all its evil forms in the strongest terms possible. Today, I am praying for Charlie Kirk’s family, his wife Erika, and their two precious young children. May the Lord grant them strength and comfort in this time of heartbreaking loss. God bless his family and loved ones.

During this week’s Appropriations Committee markup, I met with representatives from the Laredo Licensed U.S. Customs Brokers Association, along with trade leaders from Canada and Mexico, to discuss ways we can keep commerce flowing smoothly across our borders. Strengthening our ports of entry is critical, not just for security but to make trade faster, more reliable, and more competitive for businesses in South Texas and across the country.

We also talked about the importance of renewing the USMCA to provide stable and predictable conditions for cross-border trade. By modernizing our land ports and maintaining strong relationships with our neighbors, we can create jobs, support local businesses, and keep the economy moving forward.

While at the Appropriations Committee markup this week, I had the opportunity to meet with Dr. Jeff Savell, Vice Chancellor and Dean, Jennifer Yezak, Assistant Vice Chancellor, and Dustin Bryant, Associate Vice Chancellor, from @TAMU.

We discussed the challenges of protecting animal health, such as preventing screwworm outbreaks, and the vital role of research funding in keeping Texas competitive. Texas A&M is essential in addressing cross-border threats and advancing public health through food and nutrition. These conversations ensure that the needs of Texas producers, researchers, and families remain front and center in Washington.

Thanks to their leadership, South Texas and the entire state continue to lead in innovation in animal health, food security, and agriculture research. In Congress, I remain focused on strengthening support for education so every South Texan has access to the knowledge and opportunities that help our communities grow and thrive.

Today during the Appropriations Committee markup, I had the opportunity to meet with Caleb French from AFGE Council of Prison Locals 33, which represents federal correctional officers across South and Central Texas. We discussed measures to address staffing challenges, improve mental health services for officers, and ensure they have the resources needed to carry out their work safely and effectively. During our conversation, I reaffirmed my commitment to the men and women serving in federal law enforcement.

Federal correctional officers and employees work in some of the most demanding environments, putting themselves on the line every day. I will continue standing with them, making sure their voices are heard in Congress and that they have the resources they need to protect our communities. Their service keeps us safe, and they deserve nothing less than our full support.

My wife Imelda and I enjoyed a delicious meal at F&F Japanese Grill in Laredo. We appreciated the warm welcome from the staff and had a great conversation with the owners. Supporting our local businesses is always important! https://t.co/QjkbMDZzZ1

Read more from @WSJ:
https://t.co/TkMcGm9EKQ

Lumber prices are falling and that should concern every American. Mills are cutting output and builders are slowing projects because of weakening housing demand and tariff uncertainty.

I’m working with my Democrat and Republican colleagues to address these challenges head-on, fight back against tariffs causing uncertainty across our markets, and keep the housing sector moving.
Read the full piece: https://t.co/dC9lFWe2JO

FYI: The @WSJ editorial board is raising the alarm. Tariffs are stalling job growth and driving losses across manufacturing, trade, and construction.

Only 22,000 jobs were added in August, one of the weakest reports in years. That's bad news.

I’ll keep fighting in Congress to roll back these tariffs, protect American jobs, and ensure our economy remains strong.
Happy Star Trek Day, everyone! Live long, prosper, and never stop exploring whether it's space or your local community. 🖖 https://t.co/mNdTLzW1LR
Read more at @AP: https://t.co/HhVTFVz8F0

ICYMI: @conocophillips is preparing to cut up to 25% of its workforce – eliminating as many as 3,250 jobs, even after posting nearly $2 billion in profits last quarter.

These mass layoffs will ripple through families, local economies, and the energy sector that powers our nation.

I’m fighting back in Congress to create stability for workers, support energy production, and keep local communities strong.

Yesterday in Hebbronville we celebrated the release of Someone is You by Lupita Almaraz, a powerful addition to the community’s literary collection.

Stories like this remind us that literacy is more than reading. It is healing, connection, and strength.

Congratulations to Lupita on this wonderful achievement, and thank you to Distinctive Collective, Inc., County Judge Juan Carlos Guerra, and all the sponsors who helped make this event possible!

Today at Laredo City Hall, I had the honor of presenting Bishop James A. Tamayo with a Congressional Record in recognition of his lifetime of service. Mayor Victor Treviño also presented him with the Key to the City.
 
Bishop Tamayo’s life has been a blessing to our city, South Texas, and our country. Born in Brownsville, he answered the call to faith nearly fifty years ago and since then he has given everything he has to the Church, to our communities, and to the nation he served as a chaplain in the U.S. Air Force Reserve.
 
When Laredo became a diocese in 2000, Bishop Tamayo became its first bishop, building not just churches but bridges between cultures, families, and neighbors. His leadership has been defined by grace and love, a voice for the voiceless and a steady hand for those in need.
 
Today, we honor him not just for what he has done, but for who he is: a servant-leader and a light in our community.

#TX28: There's still time to apply for Service Academy nominations!

Applications are due by Oct. 31st, 2025. To request a nomination from my office, or to learn more, visit:
https://t.co/CfLmVNPjws https://t.co/CwvWptsKeT

This morning, I visited Dr. Henry Cuellar Elementary for Grandparents Day, where students had the chance to enjoy a meal with their grandparents and share all that they have learned and how they have grown.
 
Seeing the joy on the students’ faces and the pride of their grandparents was truly inspiring. These moments show the importance of family, 
community, and education in shaping the next generation!
 
I want to thank the teachers, staff, and families who make days like this possible. Celebrating our students’ growth and achievements reminds us why supporting our schools and children is so important.
Read more at @WSJ.⬇️ https://t.co/QZaT9wtk8a

🚨Today’s jobs report is one of the worst since the COVID-19 pandemic. America lost jobs in June, hiring has slowed to its weakest level since 2021, and unemployment is rising.

Let me be clear: new tariffs are driving uncertainty, raising costs, and leading to layoffs and business closures.

You deserve better. That’s why I’m working every day in Congress to lower costs, ensure clear rules of the road, and build an economy that works for everyone, not just those at the very top.
Read more below from @lmtnews.⬇️ https://t.co/7WVUBSrHyq

Thanks to $3 million in federal funding I appropriated through the Department of Education, the LEAD Project at @laredopalominos is able to continue providing students with the resources they need to make the most of their education. On Tuesday, this funding helped them launch the LEAD Center on campus, giving students access to licensed professional counselors and a dedicated space to focus on their mental and emotional health.

Supporting students is essential to building a strong future for South Texas and ensuring our communities continue to grow. In Washington, I'll keep working to deliver meaningful investments in education, giving students and instructors the necessary tools to succeed.
Quick ice cream break at the Dallas airport before heading back home to the district 🍦✈️ https://t.co/mYphyKFh0b

As part of the FY26 Defense Appropriations bill, I helped secure a 3.8% increase in basic pay for all military personnel, effective January 1, 2026.

This funding reflects our unwavering commitment to honor the service and sacrifice of our Armed Forces and to ensure their families are supported with the resources they’ve earned.🇺🇸

Recently, my Outreach Coordinators, Kelly Brooks and Adison Denham, had the honor of presenting a Congressional Recognition to Brad Stelzig and his family for their exceptional dedication to Poteet through their restaurant, The Backyard Kitchen. For more than five years, Brad and his family have gone above and beyond to create a welcoming place for neighbors, support those in need, and make remarkable personal sacrifices to serve their community.

Small businesses like The Backyard Kitchen are the backbone of South Texas, and I'm pleased to recognize the hard work, resilience, and heart it takes to run them. I'll always stand behind the entrepreneurs and staff who strengthen our communities. My team and I wish Brad and his family nothing but the best!

As part of the FY26 National Security Appropriations bill, I helped secure $1.89 billion for International Narcotics Control and Law Enforcement – to combat transnational crime, strengthen our law enforcement agencies, and disrupt illicit drug networks worldwide.

This funding reflects our commitment to closing jurisdictional gaps, supporting international allies, and promoting stability in some of the most challenging security environments.
Read more from @USATODAY. ⬇️ https://t.co/opxqccnZ3Y

In the aftermath of Republicans' budget, South Texans are continuing to face threats to health care services, and the worst is still ahead.

In TX-28 alone, nearly 115,000 people are expected to pay more for insurance because of the elimination of premium tax credits. At the same time, deep reductions to Medicaid set for 2026 are already pressuring small hospitals to scale back operations or completely close their doors. Within a decade, rural areas could see $155 billion in Medicaid spending disappear, leaving communities vulnerable when they need help most.

These higher costs and reduced services will fall hardest on rural and working-class families, which is why I opposed this partisan budget. In Congress, I'll keep fighting to defend affordable health care, protect access to essential services, and ensure no one is left behind.

Today marks four years since the tragic day when 13 brave U.S. soldiers gave their lives during the Kabul airport attack, including our own Lance Corporal David Lee Espinoza of Rio Bravo.

Lance Cpl. Espinoza was just 20 years old, a graduate of Lyndon B. Johnson High School, remembered for his courage, sense of duty, and deep love for his country. He answered the call to serve, and in doing so, made the ultimate sacrifice. His bravery and selflessness will forever live in our hearts and in the freedoms we cherish.

This morning, I held a press conference with Mayor Victor Treviño, the Laredo Police Department, the Webb County Sheriff’s Office, Chief Miguel Rodriguez, and our constables to reaffirm what families along the border already know: our communities are among the safest in America.

The FBI’s latest data shows cities along the border like Laredo and Rio Grande City continue to have some of the lowest crime rates in the nation. Laredo’s murder rate is just over 2 per 100,000 people, compared to the national rate of 5 per 100,000, while Rio Grande City reported zero murders last year. That is something we can all be proud of.

But safety is more than numbers. It means parents feel secure sending their children to school, workers can go to their jobs with peace of mind, and families can worship knowing their community and law enforcement are looking out for them.

This safety is possible because of the dedication of our officers, community leaders, and families who work together every day. In Congress, I have delivered resources to keep it that way, including nearly $58 million for Webb County through Operation Stonegarden and almost $8 million to hire new police officers in Laredo, along with millions more for community policing and school safety.

I will continue fighting in Washington to make sure our law enforcement officers have the resources they need and our families have the peace of mind they deserve. I want to thank law enforcement at the local, state, and federal levels, as well as community leaders across the southern border, for their tireless efforts to keep our communities safe.

📢National crime statistics confirm what South Texans have long known: our border communities are among the safest in the country.

The 2024 Uniform Crime Report shows violent crime and murder rates in cities like Laredo and Rio Grande City are far lower than the national average and dramatically below many large U.S. cities.

For example, Detroit recorded a murder rate of 31.17 per 100,000 residents. Baltimore, 34.8.

In Laredo, the rate was 2.32 and in Rio Grande City, zero.

Safety is more than a number – it’s families walking to church with peace of mind, parents sending their kids to school, and workers heading to the job site knowing their community is secure.

That’s why I’ll continue fighting to ensure our law enforcement officers have the resources they need to protect South Texas and keep our communities strong.

The deployment of an Aerostat in Zapata County is part of a program that enhances security, improves situational awareness, and optimizes resource allocation across the southern border.

Flying at 3,000 feet, the Aerostat serves as a visible “eye in the sky,” acting as a strong deterrent to smugglers and illegal border crossers. With real-time, wide-area surveillance that covers 20 miles of border, agents can better detect and deter illicit activity, close technology gaps, and allocate resources more effectively.

I was pleased to work in a bipartisan manner with my friend and colleague @RepMcCaul to help launch this important program, strengthening security and providing more comprehensive coverage along the southern border.

The results are clear – in FY25, nearby zones averaged 11 gotaways per month. Since the Aerostat was deployed, those same areas have seen zero. I’ll continue to work across the aisle to find ways to help secure the southern border.

In the FY26 Commerce, Justice, and Science Appropriations bill, I helped secure $2 million for Kevin and Avonte’s Law, which provides resources to help state and local law enforcement locate and protect individuals with Alzheimer’s, autism, or other developmental disabilities who wander from safe environments.

Families in South Texas and across the country deserve the peace of mind that their loved ones will be safe. This investment ensures communities have the tools to prevent tragedies and protect some of our most vulnerable neighbors.

FYI: The nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget projects federal deficits will total $22.7 trillion over the next decade. That’s $1 trillion higher than previous estimates.

This worsening outlook is driven by the partisan budget bill passed in July, which alone will add $4.6 trillion to deficits. On top of that, new tariffs are raising everyday costs and hurting working families right now.

In #TX28, an estimated 259,080 households – nearly every family in the district – will be harmed by these policies, losing an average of $2,050 in annual income.

That’s why in Congress I'm fighting to lower costs, invest federal dollars back into our communities, and ensure South Texas families keep what they earn.

Report after report has come out this week coming to the same conclusion – families and businesses are struggling to keep up with retaliatory tariffs. With many companies no longer able to shield consumers from rising import costs, families are now forced to bear the costs.

South Texans deserve the financial stability and economic certainty to plan ahead without tightening their belts. In Congress, I'm dedicated to working across the aisle to find solutions that lower the cost of living and ensure businesses are able to thrive.

90 years ago, President Roosevelt signed the Social Security Act into law, creating an essential American promise that provides retirement, disability, and survivors benefits to millions of Americans. Today, over 135,000 people in #TX28 depend on Social Security to help pay their bills, buy groceries, and live with dignity after long careers serving their families and communities.

While Republicans push to cut and privatize Social Security, I’m working to protect and enhance it – so our seniors, veterans, and families can continue to count on it for generations to come.

As part of the FY26 Interior Appropriations Bill, I helped secure $35 million for small and rural communities – including those in South Texas – to tackle the complex challenges of improving their water and wastewater systems. Across our region, too many families still face aging infrastructure, contaminated wells, and limited access to safe drinking water.

This funding will support on-the-ground experts for small water systems and well owners.

A recent report from the @USCBO confirms what we already knew – the partisan budget passed last month funds tax breaks to the wealthiest households by slashing critical health care and nutrition programs that everyday families in South Texas rely on.

While the top 10% will receive $13,600 more annually, the lowest 10% of earners will lose $1,200 every year largely due to cuts to Medicaid and SNAP. These cuts mean fewer people will get the care and food assistance they need, making it harder for working families, seniors, and the most vulnerable to make ends meet.

Instead of protecting essential services, this budget takes from those who can least afford it to reward those who need it least, which is why I voted against these dangerous cuts. I'll continue fighting for responsible, bipartisan solutions that strengthen our economy and put the needs of South Texan families first.

I was saddened to hear of the passing of Former Seguin Mayor Betty Ann Matthies, a remarkable public servant whose life was defined by compassion, leadership, and unwavering dedication to her community.

I’m working in Congress to protect these programs and ensure families can continue to get the care they need.

Today in Laredo, I joined @CityofLaredo Mayor Dr. Victor D. Treviño, El Metro Transit Director Robert J. Garza, Assistant GM Monica Garcia, local riders, and reporters for a public transit ride-along celebrating the largest fleet expansion in El Metro’s history.

Thanks to the $11.8M in federal funding I secured from @USDOT’s @FTA_DOT, El Metro has modernized its fleet with new, cleaner, more accessible buses. The addition of 19 compressed natural gas buses marks a major step forward in expanding transit options and reducing emissions across Laredo. Combined with local funds, this investment is transforming public transit by improving service, cutting emissions, and making rides safer.

These new buses connect seniors, students, workers, and families to jobs, school, healthcare, and opportunity. They also reduce Laredo’s carbon footprint and help keep our streets cleaner and healthier.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I secured this funding to ensure our community has the infrastructure it needs to thrive. Investing in green, modern transit improves quality of life, drives economic growth, and strengthens our workforce.

Thank you again to Mayor Treviño, Director Garza, Assistant GM Garcia, El Metro, and all our local leaders for making Laredo more connected than ever. I’ll keep fighting to deliver federal investments for Laredo and #TX28.

This morning in South Laredo, I joined @TxDOT Commissioner Alex Meade III, Mayor Victor Treviño, project engineers, and local leaders to break ground on the Lomas Del Sur Overpass Project.

This transformational $49.5 million investment – with 80% of the funding coming from federal dollars I secured – will ease traffic, improve safety, and support one of the fastest-growing areas in our city. The project will deliver new lanes, frontage road ramps, and a shared-use path for pedestrians and cyclists. These modern upgrades are designed to meet the needs of our growing population.

By investing our federal tax dollars into South Laredo’s infrastructure, we’re tackling long-standing congestion issues, creating good-paying jobs, strengthening our economy, and improving quality of life for our families.

ICYMI: I’m so happy to celebrate a historic step forward in preserving and uplifting Mexican American heritage. The Mexican American Museum of Texas has launched its permanent collection featuring icons like Cesar Martinez, Gil Rocha, Luis Guerra, and Jesus Toro Martinez, my San Antonio Outreach Coordinator.

I'm excited to share another important win for South Texas in this year's Homeland Security appropriations bill. I helped secure $360 million for the Assistance to Firefighter Grant Program, which helps fire departments across the country purchase life-saving equipment, vehicles, and protective gear.

This funding is vital because it ensures our first responders have the tools they need to do their jobs safely and effectively. I’ll keep working to bring home resources that support the men and women who protect us every day.

Today, in celebration of my daughter Christina’s birthday, I had the joy of taking her and her colleagues from @tamusystem, Kerry Kinirons and Janice Thomas, on their first tour of the U.S. Capitol Dome.

We had the rare opportunity to view The Apotheosis of Washington up close – a breathtaking fresco that most visitors only see from the rotunda floor, 180 feet below. Its beauty was matched only by the view that awaited us at the top. After nearly 300 steps, we stood just beneath the Statue of Freedom, looking out across the National Mall and the vast city that helps shape our nation’s future.

Standing high above the Capitol grounds, I felt the incredible honor of representing our communities in Congress – and the profound honor of being Christina’s father. Sharing this incredible experience with her, in a place so rich with history and meaning, is something I will always cherish.

Happy birthday, Christina! Watching you grow into a woman of intelligence, integrity, and compassion has been one of the greatest experiences of my life. May God bless you and watch over you always.

I'm excited to share another important win for South Texas in this year's Homeland Security appropriations bill. I helped secure $305 million for the Nonprofit Security Grant Program, which helps places of worship and other nonprofits enhance security to prevent targeted violence.

This investment is vital because no one should feel unsafe in their house of worship or community space. I’ll keep working to make sure every community has the protection and peace of mind they deserve.

Grateful to David Bradley, CEO of @NCAFNews, for meeting with me during a full day of Appropriations markups! We discussed the vital role of the Community Services Block Grant (CSBG) in #TX28.

CSBG provides flexible funding directed by local agencies to help low income families build economic self-sufficiency. Four agencies currently serving our district – the City of San Antonio Dept. of Human Services, Community Action Corporation of South Texas, Community Council of South Central Texas, and South Texas Development Council – receive a combined $2.7 million in federal support. In Congress, I’m working to protect this funding and ensure it keeps reaching the agencies delivering results for our communities.

The event celebrated the positive impact the business has made, honoring Mr. Alfonso Alvarado for his over 50 years of dedication to quality and authenticity in the industry. His longstanding commitment has enriched the community and preserved an important local tradition.

We thank Alfonso’s Tamales for their continued service and look forward to supporting their ongoing success!

U.S. Border Patrol agents face a growing challenge as cartels use civilian drones to surveil and evade law enforcement along the southern border. These off-the-shelf drones give criminal groups the ability to coordinate smuggling operations faster than ever before, threatening community safety and border security.

To address this head-on, I secured a bipartisan amendment with @RepCloudTX in the FY26 Transportation, Housing and Urban Development directing federal agencies to establish a no-drone zone within one mile of the border. This measure empowers agents to respond swiftly and maintain their tactical advantage, ensuring they can operate with speed and adjust to evolving threats.

Protecting our border means staying ahead of those who seek to exploit technology to undermine security. This amendment is a crucial step in giving our agents the tools and authority they need to keep our communities safe.

I’m pleased to share another win for South Texas, benefiting communities like Atascosa County. I helped secure $35 million in this year’s agriculture appropriations bill for Water and Waste Technical Assistance Grants. This program helps rural communities improve their water and wastewater systems by providing free technical assistance and training on water source, treatment, storage, distribution, and waste disposal, as well as support in applying for larger infrastructure funding.

This investment strengthens essential services, protects public health, and helps communities plan for long term growth. I’ll continue fighting in Congress to deliver the resources and support Atascosa County and all of South Texas deserve.

My San Antonio Outreach Coordinator, Toro Martinez, presented a Congressional Certificate of Recognition to Dr. Monica Perales of the @UTSA Institute of Texan Cultures for her outstanding contributions to community cultural enrichment.

Dr. Perales was honored for her exceptional work in historical scholarship, public humanities, and cultural preservation in Texas. Her leadership at the Institute of Texan Cultures and dedication to documenting the U.S.-Mexico borderlands have greatly enriched our understanding of diverse communities and their histories.

We thank Dr. Perales for her unwavering commitment to education, engagement, and service to our community.

I’m pleased to announce federal funding that will benefit South Texas, including Duval County. This program provides research critical to solving our nation’s largest agricultural issues.

I’ll keep advocating in Congress to bring valuable resources and opportunities to Duval County and communities across South Texas.

My San Antonio Outreach Coordinator, Kelly Brooks, attended the ACA (Atascosa Citizens for Action) community meeting. Residents and representatives showcased the help their companies can offer and discussed ways to strengthen the community through collaboration. Meetings like this are a great way to connect, share ideas, and work toward a stronger, more united Atascosa.

I’m excited to share some important wins for agriculture in South Texas, including right here in Webb County. I helped secure $111.5 million in this year’s agriculture appropriations bill for the Cattle Health program, which supports fever tick eradication to protect livestock. These efforts are especially critical along the border, where fever ticks threaten herds and the livelihoods of our ranchers.

This investment will keep the cattle industry strong, safeguard local economies, and protect the food supply we all rely on. Today, I held a press conference alongside Mayor Treviño to update the community on how the Department of Defense is supporting border security here in Laredo.
 
Last week, I toured one of the Stryker units with Mayor Treviño, Customs and Border Protection, and Army leadership to see firsthand how these armored vehicles equipped with thermal imaging and drone detection technology are helping strengthen our border security. These assets provide critical surveillance in the dense brush where illegal crossings often happen, giving Border Patrol real-time intelligence and allowing agents to respond more effectively and safely.
 
I also spoke with Major General Scott Naumann, Commander of Joint Task Force–Southwest Border, to hear directly what our troops need to succeed. The challenges we face are real and growing. Earlier this week, I was briefed on an alarming incident where an Army official was assaulted by an undocumented individual hiding in thick brush. Thankfully no one was injured, but these kinds of threats are increasing. Laredo now ranks among the top cities for cartel-operated drone activity, and the Rio Grande brush accounts for the vast majority of illegal crossings and concealment.
 
The Stryker units are already making an impact. Their cameras can detect movement as small as a mouse from over a mile away, helping Border Patrol focus resources where they are needed and deterring illegal crossings. Clearing overgrown vegetation is also critical to improving visibility and patrol mobility. The Stryker units are prepared to assist with clearing key zones in coordination with the International Boundary and Water Commission and local groups to ensure it’s done responsibly and transparently.
 
These vehicles remain on perimeter routes and use sensors, not weapons, to scan from a distance. They are not patrolling our streets or enforcing immigration law. This is a precision mission focused on deterring cartel drones, disrupting smuggling networks, and ensuring the safety of our frontline officers.
 
In Congress, I am working to fund river-road improvements, expand patrol access routes, remove Carrizo cane, and modernize federal law so Border Patrol and military units have the tools and protections they need.
 
I want to thank Mayor Treviño, Chief Muñoz, @DHSgov , @DeptofDefense , and our local law enforcement for working in lockstep to reducing cartel-drone incursions, illegal crossings, stash houses, and high-speed car chases. This unified effort across all levels of government is delivering results.
 
South Texas is strong and resilient. When we work together and lead with facts, not fear, we rise to any challenge. To every soldier, agent, and neighbor, thank you. I will keep fighting for you in Washington and listening to you here at home.

During today’s Appropriations markup, I offered an amendment to make sure every taxpayer dollar is measured and accounted for.

It’s simple: we can’t just spend – we have to track outcomes, review regulations, and demand performance. That’s how we deliver better results for the American people.

I’m looking forward to working with members of the committee in a bipartisan way to advance these practical oversight measures in the final bill.

During today’s Appropriations markup, I was pleased to help secure two provisions in the FY26 Energy and Water bill: one to improve flash flood preparedness, and another to support rehabilitation of the Amistad and Falcon Dams.

This summer’s flash flooding in Central Texas was devastating. I’m deeply familiar with the region – I live nearby, and my kids have attended summer camp around that area. I visited the flood-affected communities and spoke directly with first responders. I helped secure a provision that will ensure the @USACEHQ, in coordination with @NOAA, @USGS, and @fema, prioritize technical assistance for local communities and improve flood response planning using the best available science and data.

I also supported language ensuring Amistad Dam and Falcon Dam, serving Starr and Val Verde Counties, qualify for rehabilitation funding – not just routine maintenance. This will help address structural issues before they become emergencies.

Thank you to Chairman @rep_stevewomack and Ranking Member @RepJamesClyburn for supporting these commonsense provisions.
Watch my remarks below.⬇️ https://t.co/JErISlxgrW

During today’s Appropriations markup, the committee adopted my amendment to the FY26 Transportation, Housing and Urban Development bill to prohibit civilian drones from airspace within one mile of the southern border.

Cartels are using drones to track Border Patrol and troop movements, enabling the smuggling of drugs, weapons, and people into the U.S. These systems are growing more advanced and harder to detect, putting border communities and law enforcement at serious risk. Unlike responsible operators, cartels don’t follow regulations — they adapt quickly to evade detection. This amendment helps our agents match that agility by giving them the tools and authority to respond in real time.

Working with @RepCloudTX, we developed bipartisan language that directs @FAANews, @DHSgov, and @CBP to create a no-drone zone along the southern border. It targets illegal activity without disrupting responsible drone use. The amendment also includes clear exceptions for law enforcement, emergency responders, and legal operators like farmers and ranchers.

This sends a clear message: Congress recognizes the threat and expects federal agencies to act swiftly to counter it.

I remain committed to securing the border, protecting our communities, and ensuring law enforcement has what it needs to get the job done. I thank Chairman @rep_stevewomack and Ranking Member @RepJamesClyburn for supporting this commonsense, bipartisan step to safeguard our homeland.

My San Antonio Outreach Coordinator, Adison Denham, met with actor and founder Tony Plana at a reception for Seniors in Play to learn more about this impactful program.

Seniors in Play is a San Antonio–based initiative that brings theatrical programming to senior centers, enriching the lives of older adults through the performing arts. The program is held every Friday at two senior centers within San Antonio, engaging and uniting the senior community through creativity and culture.

It’s inspiring to see programs like this making a positive difference in the lives of our seniors and contributing to a more connected, vibrant community!

Today I took a moment to pray and reflect in the Congressional Prayer Room. It’s a quiet space near the Capitol rotunda, set aside in 1955 for Members of Congress to seek spiritual guidance.

The stained glass window shows George Washington in prayer, surrounded by the powerful words from Lincoln’s Gettysburg address, “This Nation Under God,” as well as Psalm 16:1. These symbols reflect the faith that has guided our nation through every chapter of its history.

As a Catholic, I pray daily to guide my decisions, shape my values, and ground my work on behalf of the people I serve. I’m deeply grateful for this spiritual refuge in the Capitol, where faith meets duty.

May God bless our families.
May God bless our communities.
And may God bless the United States of America.

In South Texas, folks tell me what matters: a good job, a doctor they can afford, safe schools, and a fair shot to build a better life.

That’s what a responsible budget should support.

But the partisan budget bill signed into law on July 4th does the opposite. It rewards the wealthy, punishes working families, and threatens the care and services millions of Americans rely on.

After unimaginable loss in Kerr County, it was deeply humbling to be on the ground to see the damage firsthand, thank our first responders and volunteers, and reinforce our commitment to ensuring a tragedy like this never happens again.

Thank you to our incredible first responders and volunteers, who’ve risked everything to protect lives and help our neighbors recover. The destruction is stark. But so is the strength. Everywhere I went, I saw the kind of grit and grace that defines Texas.

I received briefings from the National BORSTAR Commander on current operations, @fema's Acting Regional Administrator for Region 6, as well as the Ingram Fire Chief. And I had the chance to hear directly from those working tirelessly to help our neighbors rebuild.

I also met with statewide first responders, volunteers, and folks from Starr and Edinburg who came to lend a hand. I want to thank them for their swift, selfless action in protecting lives and property. I also want to thank our local business partners like @tacopalenque for providing meals and support to the community during this challenging time.

I'll continue to support my friend and colleague @RepChipRoy and his district as recovery efforts move forward. My thoughts remain with every family affected by these floods. May God watch over the people of Kerr County and grant comfort to those in mourning, strength to those helping others, and peace to a community that has endured far too much.

Today I joined my friend Ramiro Cavazos, President and CEO of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, for a press conference to highlight the importance of the Tomato Suspension Agreement. This is a quiet but critical trade deal that keeps grocery prices stable, trade lanes open, and our supply chains moving.

Here in Texas, over 150 businesses and thousands of workers depend on this agreement. Ending it could cost our state up to 32,000 jobs, $4.5 billion in losses, and raise tomato prices by 17 percent. Families would feel that impact directly at the grocery store.

Some have questioned the agreement’s effectiveness, but the facts are clear. Over 99 percent of imported tomatoes meet U.S. standards, with no evidence of widespread dumping. Ending it would hurt not just Mexican exporters but also American distributors, grocers, and workers.

This is an issue with broad support from businesses, trade experts, and community leaders who agree we should strengthen and modernize the agreement rather than abandon it.

The agreement also plays an important role in regional stability by supporting jobs on both sides of the border and easing the economic pressures that drive migration. I would respectfully encourage the Department of Commerce to continue engaging in good faith and give diplomacy the space it needs to deliver a solution that protects workers, consumers, and producers alike.

The Tomato Suspension Agreement is one of those behind-the-scenes policies that quietly keep our economy and communities strong. We must protect what works and improve what can be better through cooperation, common sense, and a shared commitment to fairness.

Yesterday, I had the honor of joining our community for the opening of the 21st Sister Cities Festival, an annual tradition that speaks to the heart of who we are in Laredo. This vibrant gathering celebrates not only our deep ties with Mexico and Latin America but the unity, culture, and connection that define us as a binational and bicultural community.

I’m deeply grateful to the individuals who made this celebration possible.
To Mayor Dr. Victor Treviño, thank you for your steady leadership and commitment to our city.

To Aileen Ramos and the incredible team at the Laredo Convention and Visitors Bureau, your creativity, care, and passion brought this weekend to life. And to every vendor, artist, public servant, and family who took part, gracias por ser parte de esta hermosa tradición!

This festival is more than an event. It’s a living expression of unity. It was a joy to welcome delegations from Querétaro, Tamaulipas, Oaxaca, and beyond. Each brought their unique culture and spirit, enriching this shared experience. Special thanks to our friends from Querétaro for gifting us the Giant Lele doll, an enduring symbol of heritage and pride.

To our neighbors from across the river, thank you for sharing your talents, your traditions, and your presence with us. The Rio Grande doesn’t divide us, it connects us. It’s not just a boundary; it’s a bond that nourishes a community built on family, commerce, and friendship.

As we continue the Sister Cities Festival this weekend, let’s celebrate everything that brings us together. Let’s honor our cultures, our partnerships, and the future we’re building side by side!

Today, City of Laredo Mayor Victor D. Treviño joined me to see one of the Stryker units in Laredo for a briefing with @CBP and the @DeptofDefense. We discussed challenges along the border, including stash houses, high-speed pursuits, drug smuggling, and cartel-operated drones. During the briefing, we watched a video showing how cartels are using drones to guide smugglers across the border and into the streets of Laredo.

We also discussed the capabilities of the Stryker units currently based in Laredo, which are equipped with high-resolution cameras so advanced they can detect something as small as a mouse from a mile away. These units are providing much-needed surveillance support and helping strengthen the efforts of our Border Patrol agents.

It was great to meet the men and women from the Department of Defense who have traveled from different parts of the country to assist CBP here in Laredo. They are working hand-in-hand with our agents, and their support is making a real difference. Once a Stryker unit is deployed to a location, the number of illegal crossings and related criminal activity drops considerably.

Next week, the Mayor and I will hold a press conference to highlight the important work the Department of Defense is doing in Laredo and discuss how these efforts will continue to enhance the security of our communities.

It was great to join @abbydphillip last night on @CNN to talk about the real-world challenges in #TX28, including the instability local businesses deal with from unpredictable tariffs. I’ve heard directly from job creators and their message is clear: they need certainty to plan, grow, and hire.

That’s why I’ve supported trade agreements like the USMCA, negotiated under President Trump and passed with broad bipartisan support. These agreements give our businesses a level playing field and expand access to new markets.

As a longtime advocate for free and fair trade, I’ll keep working to strengthen economic stability and protect the interests of our workers, consumers, and businesses.

I had the opportunity to visit the @amhistorymuseum with my daughters, Christina and Catie, to learn more about the conservation of the Gunboat Philadelphia – a Revolutionary War vessel now being preserved by @TAMU's own Dr. Peter Fix. The exhibit for this piece of our nation's founding will open to the public later this month for the America 250 Celebration.
 
It was a privilege to be welcomed by @smithsonian staff, Dr. Fix, and his team of experts to see their hard work preserving this artifact. Your skill and expertise have brought a centuries-old piece of history back to life, and I'm grateful to have been invited to admire it.

This week, I met with @vitro_global CEO Adrián Sada Cueva and President Ricardo Maiz to discuss manufacturing, workforce development, and how we can ensure U.S. industry stays competitive on the world stage.

Their Laredo distribution center plays a vital role in our local economy, supporting good-paying jobs and strengthening our region’s position in the global supply chain. In Congress, I'll continue to advance policies that help our employers grow and our communities thrive.

While visiting the @amhistorymuseum with my daughters yesterday, we explored the powerful exhibit on the legacy of Latino journalists in the United States. 
 
Among the many highlights was a reproduction of El Misisipi from 1808 – the nation’s first Spanish-language newspaper. We were especially proud to see exhibits honoring Laredo-native Jovita Idar, a trailblazing journalist in the early 20th century, and Martha Tijerina, a San Antonio reporter who led the way for women in Spanish-language television.

On @CNN with @abbydphillip, I spoke about the devastating flooding impacting communities across Central Texas. Let me be clear: we need to do everything we can to get first responders the resources they need and families the answers and assistance they deserve.

I’ve been closely watching the situation and those impacted – small towns overwhelmed, and local officials working around the clock with limited support.

The federal government has a responsibility to coordinate closely with state and local partners to provide immediate disaster relief, support long-term recovery, and help communities rebuild stronger. @fema's response can be improved, but strong coordination on the ground is essential.

On the Appropriations Committee, I’m focused on ensuring our national budget reflects the urgent needs of our communities. Public safety must come first, and emergency funds must be fully available, properly resourced, and ready to deploy the moment disaster strikes.

I spoke with @BlakeBurman of @NewsNation about the major problems in the partisan budget bill and why I voted no.

In Congress, I'm committed to working in a bipartisan way to deliver practical solutions for the challenges people face in our communities. When looking at this bill as a complete package, there's too much my colleagues on the other side of the aisle got wrong.

Today, I voted against the largest transfer of wealth in our nation's history. I voted against adding another $4 trillion to the national debt. I voted against raising the debt ceiling. And I voted to protect health care for 17 million Americans – including 55,000 of my constituents – who are now at risk of losing their coverage altogether.

I'll continue to support commonsense measures to reduce the cost of living, keep our southern border secure, and ensure Americans who rely on Medicaid can continue seeing their doctors and getting the care they count on.

My vote was about protecting working Americans, safeguarding critical programs, and standing up against a process that ignored fiscal responsibility. I’ll keep fighting for real solutions that put our communities first.

My San Antonio Outreach Coordinator, Jesus Martinez, recently visited the Schertz Area Senior Center to connect with local seniors and share valuable information about the services available through my office. During the visit, Jesus engaged in meaningful conversations with community members, answered questions, and provided helpful resources. He also took a moment to wish everyone a happy and safe 4th of July as we head into the holiday weekend!

Today, I voted NO on the GOP budget bill.

I've always worked across the aisle and supported responsible tax cuts, but this bill fails America, Texas, and #TX28. It adds $4 trillion to the national debt, includes the largest transfer of wealth from working families to the super-rich in our history, and makes the largest Medicaid cut ever – threatening coverage for over 55,000 people in our district. It also puts food assistance at risk for the 54,000 people in our district who rely on SNAP.

And it only gets worse at the national level.

The bill kicks 17 million Americans off their health care, slashes $1 trillion from health care programs, and jeopardizes hospitals and nursing homes. Up to 300 rural hospitals and one in four nursing homes are at risk of closing. It cuts SNAP by 20%, undercuts public schools, and burdens student borrowers.

All of this just to give the wealthiest Americans nearly $1 trillion in tax breaks.

This is not fiscal responsibility. It's just plain wrong. And that’s why I had to vote no.

ICYMI: A federal court blocked the @USDOL’s decision to "pause" Job Corps nationwide, a move that would have effectively ended the program.

Nearly 200 students in Laredo would have lost access to housing, education, and career training in skilled trades, health care, protective services, and accounting.

I'll say it again: Congress created Job Corps. Only Congress can decide its future.

This morning, I stood in solidarity with my Democratic colleagues in firm opposition to the partisan budget bill.

This is the biggest transfer of wealth from the working class to the rich in history. It's one of the largest debt ceiling increases in history. And it includes the largest cut to health care - specifically Medicaid - in our nation’s history. In just our district, nearly 55,000 people could lose health coverage. That's unacceptable.

I’ve supported responsible tax cuts in the past to help working families and small businesses. But that’s not what this bill does. It shifts the burden onto families who are just trying to get ahead while giving the biggest breaks to those who need them the least.

The people of South Texas deserve a budget that invests in their health, their education, and their future - not one that leaves them behind.

My San Antonio Outreach Coordinator, Jesus Martinez, met with Mayor Ralph Gutierrez, City of Cibolo Council member Norma Sanchez Stephens, and Col. Mel Rivera Perez in Schertz to discuss regional emergency preparedness.

They focused on creating a community business plan to help residents and small businesses respond to crises, whether natural disasters or economic challenges. They also discussed how my office can connect the community with federal resources for recovery and support.

I look forward to continuing to work with local leaders to keep our communities strong and resilient.

This morning we also took time to honor a true local hero, Mr. Robert Samuel Hill, a Vietnam War veteran whose service to our country reflects courage, sacrifice, and dedication.

Mr. Hill earned multiple military honors, including the Bronze Star Medal, the National Defense Service Medal, the Vietnam Service Medal with three Bronze Stars, the Republic of Vietnam Campaign Ribbon, and the Marksman Badge.

For decades, he had not received the Bronze Star and other medals he earned, but with support from my office, he was finally able to receive the honors he rightfully deserves.

I want to sincerely thank the other veterans who were in attendance today, as well as Mrs. Hill for her steadfast support of her husband throughout his journey. Their dedication is a powerful reminder of the enduring spirit of those who have served our nation and the families who stand alongside them.

It was a privilege to recognize Mr. Hill’s service and ensure his story of dedication and bravery is remembered for generations to come.

His example reminds us of the quiet strength and resilience shown by so many of our veterans. We are grateful for all he has done for our nation and our community.

One month ago, a young Texan sailor, Angelina Resendiz, went missing near Naval Station Norfolk and was later found dead.

I met with her mother, Esmerelda, and national veterans’ advocates to demand answers and reform from Navy officials. Families should never have to fight for basic information when a loved one in uniform goes missing. We must listen to them, honor their pain, and ensure their voices are heard at the highest levels.

Military families deserve immediate, compassionate, and transparent action when a servicemember disappears. I’m joining bipartisan calls for full transparency and accountability from the Navy. We owe it to Angelina, her family, and every servicemember to ensure real reform and lasting change.

This weekend in Laredo, I visited Buitron Academy @GlovesProf to congratulate the owner on the release of his new book. It was a great moment for our local authors, educators, and our #TX28 community.

I also stopped by @cheddarskitchen, a Texas-born spot that always brings folks together. It was great to meet the friendly waitstaff and connect with people who help make our hometown feel like family.

In Congress, I’m focused on delivering practical, bipartisan solutions that make life better for working families in our communities.
