This week I met with Esmerelda Cantu Castle, the mother of Navy sailor Angelina Resendiz, alongside Larry Romo representing @lulac, and Richard Gonzalez of @NvopAgif. Angelina was a bright young Texan whose life was tragically cut short in Norfolk. Her death has left a grieving family searching for answers.

I’m joining my Democratic and Republican colleagues in calling for a full briefing and complete transparency from the Navy. As investigations continue, families like Esmerelda’s deserve to be kept informed every step of the way.

Let me be clear: I stand with Esmerelda in demanding change. When a service member goes missing, the response must be swift, families must be notified immediately, and every effort must be made to ensure they are safe.

Our military families deserve urgency, honesty, and compassion. I’ll keep working to ensure Angelina’s legacy leads to real reform and a more accountable, responsive military for all.

ICYMI: The Border Patrol is short thousands of agents - not because of funding, but because of a broken hiring process.

My commonsense amendment gives @CBP the ability to waive polygraph exams for qualified applicants like veterans and individuals with top secret clearance. These individuals have already passed rigorous background checks - forcing them through duplicate screenings slows hiring and wastes resources.

This change gives CBP the flexibility to decide when the test is truly needed. We can’t secure the border if we can’t hire agents. That's why I’m committed to simplifying recruitment and making smart, balanced reforms that keep our communities safe.

I had a great time visiting with students from @unitedisd here in Washington today. These sharp young Texans from #TX28 brought thoughtful questions and a lot of heart to our conversation.

We talked about the work we’re doing in Congress, and I gave them a behind-the-scenes look at today’s Appropriations Committee markup. It’s always a pleasure to share the legislative process with the next generation (and even better when they’re from South Texas!)

I was also glad to introduce them to my friend and colleague from the great state of South Carolina, @RepJamesClyburn - a true statesman and leader in the House.

It's inspiring to see these students representing our community with such poise and promise. Keep it up!

Happy 33rd anniversary to my wonderful wife, Imelda. Your love, strength, and support have been the foundation of everything we've built together. I’ve helped secure over $1 billion in federal funding for Bexar County, working alongside my colleagues Rep. Tony Gonzales, Rep. Joaquin Castro, Rep. Chip Roy, and Rep. Greg Casar, who also represent this region. Through the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and the Inflation Reduction Act, these investments are driving 88 major projects that are boosting our community.

From widening key highways like SL 1604 and IH 10 to expanding capacity at San Antonio International Airport, we’re tackling congestion and improving roadway safety.

I’m also leading efforts to expand access to public transit and make our streets safer for seniors and individuals with disabilities.

The 2025 @TxDOT Unified Transportation Program supports this vision with more than $2.3 billion authorized for Bexar County, with nearly 80% of that total coming from federal dollars fueling this transformation.

This is how I’m delivering bold, game-changing results that build a stronger, faster, and more connected Bexar County for everyone!

I was honored to welcome Fr. Jacek Kostuch and parishioners from the Catholic community to mark the 10th anniversary of Laudato si’, Pope Francis’s influential encyclical. I’m bringing over $779 million to Guadalupe County to help support transportation projects, with more than $614 million of that coming from federal funds I fought to secure.

We’re also expanding access and reliability at the New Braunfels National Airport through multi-year funding, and supporting forward-looking plans like Seguin’s Safe Streets and Roads for All.

This is what it looks like when federal investment meets local impact. I’ll keep pushing to make sure Guadalupe County stays on the move!

This morning, I had the opportunity to sit down for a conversation with representatives from @TAASA to discuss advancing policies that support survivors, strengthen prevention efforts, and ensure communities across Texas have the tools they need to combat sexual violence.

Thanks to the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, I’ve secured Starr County over $6.2 million in federal funding for 8 critical projects, including traffic signal installation, safety improvements, planning support, and flood prevention work at Olmitos and Garcias Creek Sites 5 and 6.

I met with @CivilGovernment today to discuss the importance of restoring civility and mutual respect in our political discourse. This year, I secured over $20.7 million in federal funding to deliver major infrastructure upgrades in Atascosa County through the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law.

FYI: The partisan budget bill guts Pell Grants, raises student loan costs, and makes it harder for working students and adult learners to get the education they need.

Pell Grants help low and middle income students afford college without taking on overwhelming debt. In total, the GOP plan would cut $300 billion in education support by overhauling student loan limits, enforcing stricter repayment terms, and ending subsidized loans for low income undergraduates.

Instead of investing in the next generation and growing our economy, this bill pulls the ladder out behind those trying to earn a degree. I’m committed to working on bipartisan solutions that expand opportunity, not limit it.

During today’s Appropriations Homeland Security markup, I spoke in support of my bipartisan amendment to expand access to H-2A and H-2B visas for agricultural and seasonal workers, including circus and carnival staff.

This is personal to me. My father came to this country as a migrant worker and built a better life for our family through hard, honest work.

By law, employers must first actively recruit American workers. But even with these efforts, seasonal employers in rural areas still struggle to fill roles due to the nature, timing, or location of the work.

This amendment helps strengthen our food supply, supports local economies, and protects full-time American jobs that depend on a reliable supplemental workforce.

Through my work on the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and the Inflation Reduction Act, Webb County is securing over $332 million in federal funding for 34 major projects.

These include road resurfacing, interchange improvements on US 59, bridge replacements, public transit support, airport upgrades, and environmental investments.

I also ensure that more than $1.49 billion in transportation funding goes to Webb County in the 2025 @TxDOT Unified Transportation Program.

When we improve our roads, we improve opportunities for our citizens and economy.

This afternoon, I had the opportunity to meet with members of @afspnational to address the ongoing suicide crisis, particularly among our veterans and mental health professionals.

These tireless advocates took the time to meet with me during a busy Homeland Security Committee markup, and I deeply appreciate their leadership and dedication to this issue.

I've worked to address this crisis head-on in Congress, including securing key language in this year’s Appropriations bill supporting the @DeptVetAffairs' firearm lockbox program. This program is a critical element of veteran suicide prevention, ensuring Veterans Crisis Line employees are trained to assist veterans with accessing proper firearm storage resources.

I'll continue working to secure the resources needed to support those at risk and protect lives across our communities.

In securing over $36.6 million in federal funding for major infrastructure upgrades in Zapata County, I’m paving the way for major growth in South Texas. 

This includes nearly $30 million to widen US 83, improving safety and easing congestion on one of the most important corridors in South Texas.

Another $4 million is going toward preventive maintenance across key routes like IH 2, FM 1017, and FM 2061, keeping our roads in top shape and extending their lifespan. An additional $3 million will support right of way improvements along US 83, helping prepare for future growth.

On top of that, I helped lock down more than $276 million in planned investments for Zapata County through the 2025 @TxDOT’s Unified Transportation Program. This program includes over $220 million in federal funding.

These projects are game-changers for Zapata, creating jobs, improving connectivity, and laying the foundation for long-term economic development.

I spoke during today's Appropriations Homeland Security markup in support of my amendment to streamline @CBP hiring while maintaining national security. Let's be clear: Congress has set a firm goal of 22,000 active Border Patrol agents.

In order to meet this goal, it’s critical that we cut red tape for qualified veterans and applicants with existing security clearances. I’ll keep fighting for practical solutions to get agents on the ground and keep our southern border secure.

I'd like to thank Chairman @MarkAmodeiNV2 and Ranking Member @RepUnderwood for supporting this commonsense amendment.

Today in Webb County, I visited two families whose homes have been repaired thanks to a $2 million federal earmark I secured to improve housing conditions in Webb and Zapata counties.

The federal funds, with $1 million for Webb County and $1 million for Zapata County, were awarded to @nwlaredo to weatherize and repair dozens of homes in rural communities like El Cenizo, Rio Bravo, Mirando City, and Oilton. These critical renovations lower utility costs, increase accessibility through ADA-compliant upgrades, and provide safe, livable housing for families who too often lack access to home improvement resources.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I was proud to secure this funding through the Community Project Funding process. In Webb County, Phase 1 of the project is already complete, with 17 homes repaired in El Cenizo and Rio Bravo. Phase 2 is now in progress, with work underway in Mirando City and Oilton.

This investment is more than just construction. It is about ensuring dignity, safety, and long-term savings for families in need.

Thank you to NeighborWorks Laredo CEO Elizabeth Alonzo-Villarreal, Rio Bravo Mayor Amanda Perez Aguero, El Cenizo Mayor Carina Hernandez, our local leaders, and the contractors on the ground for turning this funding into meaningful change. I will keep working to deliver results for our communities.

This afternoon in Starr County, it was a pleasure to join the @SCMH1975 Board and administrative team for a roundtable discussion about protecting healthcare in our community.

We met as rural healthcare faces serious threats. Proposed federal cuts to Medicaid and rollbacks to the Affordable Care Act would devastate access to care, putting over 54,000 people in TX-28 at risk of losing coverage, including 46,000 through Medicaid alone.

Texas already runs one of the most efficient Medicaid programs in the country. These GOP cuts could strip up to $55 billion in funding, threaten 142,000 healthcare jobs, and severely impact rural hospitals, many of which already operate at a loss.

Rural hospitals like Starr County Memorial are the backbone of our communities. We must protect the coverage, services, and jobs they provide.

I am grateful to the Hospital Board and team for their leadership, and I will keep fighting in Congress to ensure our communities in South Texas get the care and support they deserve.

Only 67% of Republicans support it. 71% of independents oppose it. Let’s be clear about why: the partisan budget bill cuts health care and food assistance to pay for tax breaks for the wealthy. The more Americans learn about it, the more they reject it.

Happy Juneteenth! On June 19, 1865, freedom finally reached the last enslaved people in Galveston, Texas, more than two years after President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation.

Today, we honor their experience, reflect on how far we’ve come, and recommit ourselves to the work that lies ahead. Progress takes time, effort, and grit - and Juneteenth reminds us why we keep moving forward. I'm proud to have been an original cosponsor with former Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee to federally commemorate this powerful moment.🇺🇸

This morning in San Antonio, I joined Larry Carter, President of the @BCBSA1, along with community members and volunteers, to honor a powerful legacy of service and sacrifice.

The Buffalo Soldiers were among the first to serve in uniform after the Civil War—many of them formerly enslaved. They answered the call of duty with honor and distinction, even when their country had yet to grant them full rights.

Today, their legacy endures through the work of the Association here in Bexar County. They preserve history, educate the public, and inspire future generations.

I was proud to present the Association with a Congressional Certificate of Recognition—an expression of our deep gratitude and a commitment to ensuring their story continues to be told.

Thank you to the Buffalo Soldiers and to the Association for keeping this extraordinary legacy alive!

I was pleased today to officially announce the presidential approval of the Colombia Solidarity Bridge expansion—a major victory for Laredo and for the future of trade between the United States and Mexico.

With this latest permit, Laredo becomes the first region on the U.S.-Mexico border to secure five presidential authorizations for international bridges—an unprecedented achievement that reflects years of planning, advocacy, and collaboration across all levels of government. I want to thank @realDonaldTrump, Senators @tedcruz and @JohnCornyn, and our local partners at @cityoflaredo for their critical support in getting this done.

Laredo is now the #9 largest port globally, fueled by booming U.S.-Mexico trade. We hold more presidential bridge permits than any other border region. The World Trade Bridge is the #1 busiest land port in the U.S., and the Colombia Solidarity Bridge ranks as the #3 busiest land port in the southwest. This new expansion only strengthens our position as a global trade leader.

This is a transformational investment in Laredo’s infrastructure and a clear signal that we’re serious about strengthening our role in international commerce. Last year, we processed more than $300 billion in U.S.-Mexico trade through our port. With this expansion, we’re ready to handle even more.

Laredo has always been where trade drives progress and opportunity reaches across borders. I’m proud this project will keep it that way for the future.

@realDonaldTrump @SenTedCruz @JohnCornyn @WhiteHouse @POTUS Read the full announcement from @WhiteHouse here: 
https://t.co/RFGoQrbhgJ

🚨HISTORIC BRIDGE EXPANSION WIN FOR LAREDO🚨

President @realDonaldTrump has officially approved the Colombia Solidarity Bridge expansion - the latest in a series of major bridge projects unlocking cross-border trade for our region.

This brings the total to five international bridge projects in Laredo that now hold presidential permits. That’s the most ever approved for a single region on the U.S.-Mexico border. These projects include:

✅ The World Trade Bridge expansion.
✅ The Colombia Solidarity Bridge expansion.
✅ The Green Corridors Intelligent Freight Transportation System.
✅ The Laredo 4/5 International Bridge.
✅ The Kansas City Southern International Bridge.

The World Trade Bridge is now the most active land port in the United States. The Colombia Solidarity Bridge ranks as the third busiest in the southwest U.S.

Laredo is already the ninth largest port in the world and this expansion will help us meet rising demand, ease congestion, and supercharge trade.

The Colombia expansion includes new southbound and northbound commercial bridge spans, allowing the existing bridge to handle FAST commercial vehicles and oversized traffic. It will also create dedicated lanes for non-commercial vehicles and buses, streamlining traffic flow and modernizing one of the most critical ports on the U.S.-Mexico border.

This is part of a broader effort to position the Port of Laredo to accommodate the growing volume of U.S.-Mexico trade, which surpassed $300 billion in 2023.

I’d like to extend my special thanks to @SenTedCruz and @JohnCornyn for their partnership and to @realDonaldTrump for delivering this latest permit and helping keep Laredo at the heart of the American economy.

Laredo doesn’t just move freight: we move America.

My Laredo Outreach Coordinator, Melissa Peña, joined city leaders, transit officials, and community members to celebrate a major milestone for public transportation in our city made possible by federal dollars I helped secure: the expansion of El Metro Transit’s fleet, the largest in Laredo’s history.

This achievement was driven by federal funding from the U.S. Department of Transportation’s Federal Transit Administration, including $7.4 million from the Low or No Emission Bus Program and $4.4 million from the Urbanized Area Formula Grants. With these federal funds and local matching support, El Metro has added 19 brand new compressed natural gas buses to its fleet, significantly expanding access to clean, reliable transportation for our community.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I remain committed to fighting for federal dollars to support infrastructure projects that improve quality of life in South Texas.

With more reliable routes, improved air quality, and expanded service for seniors, students, workers, and families, El Metro is helping connect our residents to jobs, education, healthcare, and opportunity. Public transportation is more than just a ride, it is a lifeline.

I thank Mayor Dr. Victor Treviño, @officialcityoflaredo, @metro_transit, and all our local partners for their leadership in delivering a modern, sustainable, and accessible transit system for the people of Laredo. I am especially grateful to the El Metro drivers, maintenance workers, General Manager Robert Garza, and Assistant General Manager Monica Garcia. Their dedication keeps our city moving every day. Together, we are building a stronger, more connected community.

I’m proud to be the first member of Congress to complete and graduate from the U.S. @NavalWarCollege’s Master’s Program in Defense and Strategic Studies after more than three years of coursework.

This degree strengthens my work on the Defense, Military Construction and Veterans Affairs, and Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittees, where I fight every day to ensure our servicemembers, veterans, and first responders have the support they've earned. The courage and commitment of the men and women in uniform who serve our country continue to inspire me every day.

I’d like to offer my sincere thanks to the U.S. Naval War College, its administrators, and its world-class educators for their dedication to training military leaders from the United States and allied nations around the world.

Education is one of the greatest investments we can make – in ourselves, in our service, and in the future of this country.

Today, I’m proud to graduate from the U.S. @NavalWarCollege in Rhode Island, where I’ve earned a Master’s Degree in Defense and Strategic Studies.

It’s an incredible honor to walk across the stage alongside so many distinguished servicemembers and public servants dedicated to strengthening our national security.

Lifelong learning is a force multiplier. This degree sharpens my mission on the Defense, Military Construction and Veterans Affairs, and Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittees.

It was an honor to welcome Gabriel Lerma – this year’s #TX28 Congressional Art Competition winner – and his mother, Lety, to the U.S. Capitol!🎨

Gabriel’s painting, Texas Spirit, will hang in the Capitol tunnels for the next year. A fellow @nixonLISD graduate, he reminds us that art can be a powerful form of service. Gabriel, you make Laredo proud.

Through my work on the Appropriations Committee, I fought to ensure key language was included to strengthen care for veterans facing substance use challenges.
 
This week, I helped secure $232.9 million to expand Substance Use Disorder treatment at the VA. This funding will enhance provider training and introduce new online tools to better support veterans in recovery.
 
I also helped secure funding for the creation of a new pilot program that applies advanced medical technology to reduce diabetic amputations and prevent insulin-related emergencies. These are life-saving investments for our veteran community.
 
We owe it to every veteran to deliver the best possible care, and this bill moves us closer to that promise. Proud to work alongside @DeptVetAffairs to support those who’ve served.

I rose during today’s Defense Appropriations Bill markup to offer an amendment focused on ensuring that federal agencies deliver real results.

My amendment strengthens oversight, increases competition, and ties performance to clear, measurable outcomes. This means agencies are held accountable and taxpayer dollars are spent wisely.

I look forward to continuing this work with my Democrat and Republican colleagues as this performance measure moves forward.

As a member of the Appropriations Committee, I requested and secured language to deliver the largest investment yet in veterans’ mental health services.
 
We’re providing $698 million for VA suicide prevention outreach – a $139 million increase – to strengthen lifesaving care for those at risk.
 
The bill also expands the VA’s secure firearm storage program and launches a new $10 million pilot to connect veterans with service dogs for PTSD and mental health recovery.
 
These investments will save lives and reaffirm our commitment to supporting those who’ve worn the uniform.

During this week’s midnight Appropriations markup, I offered an amendment to strengthen contract oversight, boost competition, and require real performance results across federal agencies.

These reforms will ensure taxpayer dollars go further for our veterans and all Americans. I look forward to working with Chairman @JudgeCarter and Ranking Member @DWStweets to include this language in the final bill.

ICYMI: At today’s Oversight hearing, I pressed @SecDef Hegseth, @thejointstaff Chairman Gen. Caine, and @DeptofDefense Comptroller MacDonnell on the proposal to consolidate Army North and Army South and move the new command out of San Antonio.

Relocating would impact 11,900 active-duty troops currently deployed under Title 10 authority - threatening readiness, jobs, and military families.

As of today, San Antonio has invested $20M in new facilities and to improve key military medical missions. It also hosts Air Forces Cyber, which is essential to our nation's cybersecurity.

Let me be clear: I’ll keep working with the Texas delegation to protect our servicemembers, strengthen Texas, and ensure border security.

Watch my full line of questioning.⬇️

At today’s Oversight hearing with @SecDef Pete Hegseth, @thejointstaff Chairman General Dan Caine, and @DeptofDefense Comptroller Bryn MacDonnell, I raised serious concerns about the proposal to consolidate Army North and South and move the command out of San Antonio.

Army North plays a vital role supporting @DHSgov on the southern border with surveillance, logistics, engineering, and medical assistance. Relocating it risks undermining mission effectiveness at a time when 11,900 active-duty troops are deployed under Title 10 authority as part of Joint Task Force–Southern Border.

This decision would impact not just national security, but also our local economy. The military is San Antonio’s top employer, and the community has already invested $20M in new facilities to enhance its role as a hub for military medical missions. San Antonio also hosts the Sixteenth Air Force (Air Forces Cyber), a key component of our nation’s cyber defense. This move would disrupt military families who’ve already relocated to support these critical missions.

San Antonio has the infrastructure, workforce, and strategic location to support our national defense. I’ll continue fighting to keep these vital missions right here - close to the border they’re tasked with protecting.

I look forward to continuing these conversations to ensure our national security decisions strengthen, not weaken, border readiness and Texas communities. I’ll continue working with our San Antonio delegation, and the entire Texas delegation, to keep these missions in place, protect our servicemembers and families, and ensure South Texas remains at the center of our national defense strategy.

Thanks to federal dollars, students and families in our communities can now access free meals through the Summer Meals Program, administered by the @TexasDeptofAg, now through August 6.

This important program provides children from low-income families, up to age 18 or 21 for students with disabilities, access to nutritious meals while school is out. No application, ID, or registration is required. Parents are encouraged to call ahead to confirm times and locations.

To make things easier, the Texas Department of Agriculture has created a meal site map where families can locate nearby pickup points. You can access the map by visiting the Texas Department of Agriculture’s website.

This vital resource, made possible through federal funding, helps ensure no child goes hungry during the summer months. Today I was proud to stand at the @ThePortofCC as an appropriator to celebrate a major milestone for South Texas, the completion of a federal  $625 million dollar channel improvement project. This effort will power our economy, strengthen national security, and expand our global competitiveness.

This is not just infrastructure. It is an investment in opportunity. It shows what is possible when we build smart and work together for a stronger, safer, and more prosperous future.

As one of only three Strategic Military Seaports in Texas, the Port of Corpus Christi is vital to both our economic strength and national defense. With this project complete, the Port is now ready to lead in energy independence and global trade.

Corpus Christi has become the nation’s largest energy export gateway, due in part to my working on legislation with Rep. Joe Barton to lift the U.S. oil export ban in 2015. I have also worked to ensure the federal government not only funds ports like this but truly understands their importance.

This achievement reflects true partnership. Thank you to Congressman Michael Cloud, former Congressman Solomon Ortiz, Brigadier General George H. Walter for your leadership.

Together with the Port of Laredo, Corpus Christi forms a vital trade corridor linking our region to the world!

To every worker, engineer, and advocate who made this happen, thank you. You built more than a channel. You built a legacy.

It was an honor to join the Laredo community to celebrate Dr. Sylvia Guerra Rios and her extraordinary 48-year career in education!

From her roots in Hebbronville to her leadership as Superintendent of LISD, Dr. Rios has dedicated her life to lifting up students, educators, and families, always with compassion, excellence, and a servant’s heart.

Today, I held a press conference in Laredo to stand with our community in the fight against the opioid and fentanyl crisis. This is a crisis that has taken far too many lives, but one that this community is confronting with courage and unity.

Together, we recognized the deep toll this epidemic has taken on our families, our neighborhoods, and our way of life. Many lives in Webb County have been lost to fentanyl. Each one was a loved and valued member of our community. But in the face of that pain, Laredo did not stay silent or still. You came together, took action, and chose to fight back.

Thanks to the extraordinary leadership of individuals like Mayor Dr. Victor D. Treviño, Deputy Fire Chief Roberto Gonzalez, Police Chief Miguel A. Rodriguez Jr., and Sheriff Martin Cuellar, along with our educators, health professionals, law enforcement, and countless community partners, overdose deaths in Webb County dropped by 52 percent in just one year. That is real progress and a testament to what is possible when a community works together.

Nearly five million dollars in federal support has helped fund prevention, treatment, and recovery efforts, including expanded Narcan access. But the driving force behind this change is right here in Laredo. It is in the people who refused to lose another life without a fight.

As part of today’s conference, I was proud to present Congressional Certificates of Recognition to several law enforcement agencies and community organizations for their outstanding efforts in combating substance abuse and saving lives. Their dedication has made a lasting impact and continues to protect and uplift our community.

To everyone making a difference on the ground, thank you. You are proving that hope is stronger than fear and that even in the face of crisis, Laredo leads with compassion, strength, and resolve.

This morning I joined Commissioner Wawi Tijerina, local Webb County officials and staff, USDA Area Director Roel Gomez, and Enriqueta Caballero from the Texas Water Development Board for a productive meeting focused on water development and infrastructure improvements in Webb County. Last night, I joined the Laredo community at the Salvation Army’s “Doing the Most Good Dinner,” a powerful celebration of service, compassion, and faith.

For over 104 years, The Salvation Army of Laredo has been a steady source of hope, feeding the hungry, sheltering the homeless, and reminding us of God’s enduring love.

I was proud to present Congressional Certificates of Recognition to outstanding individuals whose service reflects the very best of our community. Chad Hennings, a U.S. Air Force veteran and three-time Super Bowl champion, was honored for his unwavering commitment to faith-driven leadership. Mr. Bill Green, publisher of the Laredo Morning Times, received the inaugural ‘Hometown Hero’ award for his dedication to honest, community-centered journalism. Majors Rojelio and Rebecca Galabeas were recognized for six years of faithful leadership in Laredo, where they expanded outreach, led disaster relief efforts, and provided comfort to families in need with compassion and grace.

These honorees remind us that true leadership is measured in service and that together, we can continue to do the most good.

This morning in Pleasanton, I had the pleasure of joining city and community leaders to break ground on a project that marks a bold step forward for Atascosa County.

Thanks to a $1.71 million federal investment from the USDA Rural Development Community Facilities Program, Pleasanton Municipal Airport is building a new hangar. It will house up to eight aircraft, generate revenue, and expand services for local businesses, freight operations, and emergency response. Together, these efforts are strengthening the city’s role as a key part of our regional aviation network.

A heartfelt thank you to those whose leadership and hard work made this day possible: Mayor JR Gallegos, Mayor Pro-tem Joey Macon, the Pleasanton City Council, Bond Counsel Carey Troell, USDA partner Betty Soto, Brian Cope of COPE Engineering, Roger Wells of Wells Construction, City Manager Johnny Huizar, Finance Director Raquel Navarro, Assistant Finance Director Cassie Garcia, City Attorney Bobby Maldonado, Airport Manager JJ Roberts, and Ernie Gonzalez of EMC Strategy Group.
Your dedication to this city is laying the foundation for smart, lasting growth.

This hangar represents more than just infrastructure. It reflects the momentum building in Pleasanton and the bright future we are working toward together!

This morning in Laredo, I had the privilege of honoring two pillars of our community during a special recognition ceremony. One was for a lifetime of public service and the other for preserving the legacy of our shared history.

First, I recognized Mayor Dr. Victor D. Treviño for his decades of unwavering service to the people of Laredo. From his roots at Nixon High School to his leadership as our City Health Authority during the COVID-19 pandemic, Mayor Treviño has always led with compassion, humility, and purpose. His efforts, including a binational vaccination campaign that administered nearly 300,000 vaccines, saved lives and brought communities together in a time of crisis. Today, I proudly presented him with a Congressional Record entry to honor his lifelong dedication to public health and service.

I also had the honor of recognizing the Order of Granaderos y Damas de Gálvez as they celebrate 50 years of preserving and promoting the vital but often overlooked role Spain played in the American Revolution. From their beginnings in San Antonio to the continued work of the Laredo Chapter, their mission is clear: to ensure that figures like General Bernardo de Gálvez are remembered for their courageous contributions to our nation’s founding. Their efforts earned them a well-deserved entry into the Congressional Record as well.

This ceremony was a meaningful acknowledgment of the individuals and organizations whose work strengthens our community, whether through public service or the preservation of history. Their contributions remind us of the value of leadership, dedication, and a deeper understanding of where we come from.

It was a true honor to join veterans, families, and community members today at VFW Post 4676 in Universal City, a place where service, sacrifice, and community come together.

Thank you to Commander Melvin Yamamoto, Jr. Vice Commander Charlie “Chief” Mechling, Incoming Sr. Vice Commander and House Chairman Paul Yingst, and Mayor Tom Maxwell for your leadership and dedication.

The VFW has been a pillar of veteran advocacy since 1899, built not just on remembrance but on action. Post 4676 lives that mission every day.

As part of Post’s Memorial Day ceremony, I had the pleasure of presenting Congressional Certificates of Recognition to three exceptional young people: Russel Yalowsky, Alyssa Diaz, and Isabella “Bella” Garza. They were also awarded scholarships for their academic achievements and commitment to service. Each of them read aloud the essays that earned them this honor, offering powerful reflections on patriotism, sacrifice, and civic responsibility.

May we honor the memory of all who have served and sacrificed, not just today but every day.

It was an honor to join veterans, families, and community members at American Legion Post 828 on San Antonio’s East Side, a post with deep roots and a proud history. Founded by Black veterans after World War II, Post 828 has stood as a lasting symbol of service, strength, and unity.

Thank you to Commander Burrell Parmer and Marine Corps veteran Richard Delgado Jr. for your continued commitment to this community. Richard’s dedication, both in uniform and through civic engagement, is a powerful example of leadership that extends beyond military service.

On Memorial Day, we remember those who gave their lives in service to our country, and we reaffirm our commitment to supporting the people and principles they fought to defend.

As a member of Congress, I will continue working to ensure that veterans receive the care and benefits they have earned.

May we honor their service not just with words, but through meaningful action.

Today, I had the profound honor of joining veterans, families, and community leaders at Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery, a sacred place that reminded us not just of the cost of freedom but of the courage that defends it. I also had the privilege of speaking at the ceremony, where we came together in reflection, remembrance, and recommitment.

I’d like to recognize the extraordinary team who care for these hallowed grounds with such dignity and compassion: Director Jerry Lefler, Assistant Director Graham Wright, and every dedicated staff member who ensures that every hero laid to rest there is honored with the respect they deserve. Thank you as well to Julianne Flynn, Executive Director of VA South Texas Health Care, and John Mendoza, Deputy Medical Center Director of VA South Texas Health Care, for your leadership and steadfast support of our veterans and their families.

To the veterans who joined us, to the Gold Star families whose strength humbles us all, and to the men and women of the Department of Veterans Affairs, your presence was a powerful tribute to those we came to remember. Your continued service and sacrifice speak volumes.

On this Memorial Day, communities across the country paused to reflect. But there, among the headstones, we did more than remember. We honored. We recommitted ourselves to the values these men and women lived and died for.

Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery stands as more than a final resting place. It is a powerful testament to the legacy of those who served our nation with courage and conviction. Each grave told a story of someone who believed in something greater than themselves.

As a proud Texan and member of Congress, I was reminded once again how deeply service is woven into the fabric of our state. In San Antonio, Military City USA, service is not just a tradition. It is a way of life.

To the families of the fallen, your quiet strength and grace reminded us all what it means to carry the weight of loss with dignity. Your sacrifice will never be forgotten. We must ensure that the values these heroes defended remain at the heart of our nation.

May God bless our veterans, their families, and all those who serve. And may God forever bless the United States of America.

We have lost a true giant in American politics with the passing of former Congressman Charles Rangel. A proud son of Harlem, Korean War veteran, and founding member of the Congressional Black Caucus, he served New York and our nation with unwavering dedication for 46 years. He was a tireless champion for justice, equality, and opportunity. My thoughts and prayers are with his family, loved ones, and all who are mourning this extraordinary loss.

Today I had the honor of joining veterans, families, and community leaders at VFW Post 8397 in San Antonio, now renamed in tribute to Lance Corporal David Lee Espinosa.

I thank the family of Lance Corporal Espinosa for their presence, their strength, and the sacrifice they continue to carry with such grace. I also want to thank Commander Charleen G. Hernandez and every member of Post 8397 for their hospitality, their leadership, and their unwavering dedication to remembrance. To every veteran that was in attendance, to the families, and to every guest who came to honor our fallen, thank you.

Lance Corporal David Lee Espinosa was born in Laredo, raised in Rio Bravo, graduated from LBJ High School, and like so many who wear our nation’s uniform, he believed in something larger than himself. He believed in service. In sacrifice. In standing up when others stand back.

The renaming of this post is more than a tribute. It is a promise to remember his legacy and uphold the values he lived and died for.

May God bless Lance Corporal David Lee Espinosa and may God continue to bless the United States of America.

This afternoon, I joined leaders at the Colombia Solidarity Bridge, a vital connection between our countries and communities.

I thanked Governor Samuel Alejandro García Sepúlveda of Nuevo León and Mayor of Laredo Victor Treviño for their leadership. I also expressed my appreciation to our military, CBP agents, and their Mexican counterparts for their professionalism and commitment to public safety and human dignity.

Thanks to strong local leadership and recent progress, including the State Department’s foreign policy recommendation, we are advancing a major expansion that includes two new spans, dedicated lanes, and modern infrastructure to reduce congestion and support economic growth.

The Port of Laredo is already the nation’s busiest land port, with the industrial boom in Nuevo León and a deeply integrated supply chain, this region is critical to the future of North American trade.

Our goal is clear: safer, faster, smarter crossings that strengthen commerce and community.

Today, we reaffirmed that border security and strong partnerships go hand in hand. Together, we are shaping a future that is secure, prosperous, and united!

This morning, I had the honor of joining friends, neighbors, and community leaders at the historic Plaza San Agustin to celebrate a truly remarkable milestone: 270 years of continuous community, culture, and courage in the City of Laredo.

Standing in the heart of a city older than the nation itself, I was proud to recognize the people and partnerships that made this day possible. From Mayor Dr. Victor Treviño’s leadership to the tireless efforts of the Webb County Heritage Foundation and Andrea Ordoñez. Together with educators, cultural groups, and everyday citizens, they remind us that history lives on through the people who carry it forward.

Laredo is not just a border town. It is a borderland civilization. A city where seven flags have flown, where commerce and culture meet, and where generations have grown up bilingual, proud, and deeply rooted. As we reflect on our past, we also look ahead with hope and determination to build a future worthy of our legacy.

Feliz cumpleaños, Laredo! Here’s to 270 years and many more to come!

This afternoon, I had the honor of meeting with the next generation of leaders from @us_awc. We discussed military readiness, the execution of joint operations, and how Congress plays a role in supporting our military to achieve its missions.

With your skill, dedication, and vision for service, the future of our national security is in excellent hands.

This morning, during our Appropriations Oversight Hearing, I spoke with @CBP Acting Commissioner Pete Flores to examine the agency’s operations and funding priorities. It’s essential that we provide CBP with the tools they need to keep our border secure and our communities safe.

I raised several key issues: the critical expansion of Checkpoint 29 in Laredo, where delays pose safety risks, and concerns about waste processing at the new Joint Processing Center - where better collaboration with @cityoflaredo is needed to find a workable, long-term solution. I also raised the need for a new BP checkpoint in Freer, Texas.

I’m grateful to Acting Commissioner Flores for his testimony and decades of service. These projects aren’t just line items; they’re about ensuring Laredo and Freer’s infrastructure keeps pace with their roles as vital hubs for border security.

Great to meet with Officer Ricardo Salinas from the @CBP Laredo Field Office during his visit to D.C. His work - and that of the entire team - is critical to keeping our communities and country safe. I’m proud to see South Texas represented with such integrity and dedication.

It was also an honor to congratulate Ricardo on the @DFOLaredo Drill Team's third place finish at this week’s Steve Young National Honor Guard Exhibition and Tribute. This competition exemplifies the highest standards of honor and discipline and it’s no surprise that our outstanding officers from Laredo rose to the occasion.

Keep making #TX28 proud!

Today, I spoke with my friend and former colleague in the House, @SecVetAffairs Douglas Collins, during an Appropriations Committee Oversight Hearing to discuss the @DeptVetAffairs' efforts to support our veterans.

I raised concerns about the financial strain veterans face when they’re asked to repay benefits because of overpayments stemming from administrative errors (and through no fault of their own.)

I appreciated Secretary Collins’ thoughtful response and commitment to improving these systems. Our veterans deserve a VA that works for them.

I’ll keep working in Congress to ensure they receive the care and benefits they’ve earned, without unnecessary hurdles.

Today, I heard directly from Secretary of the Navy @SECNAV John Phelan, Admiral James Kilby, and @CMC_MarineCorps General Eric Smith about the critical challenges confronting our Navy and Marine Corps. We discussed the essential capabilities these branches bring to our national security and global readiness.

I raised serious concerns about persistent issues with cost overruns and schedule delays in military programs. As we move forward, I remain committed to working across the aisle to ensure our service members have the tools, support, and resources they need to fulfill their mission effectively.🇺🇸

Today I met with General Steven Nordhaus, @ChiefNGB, to discuss the critical role of the National Guard in supporting our defense and emergency response efforts. We discussed priorities for the @USNationalGuard, including ensuring any border support roles remain transparent, compliant, and focused on non-enforcement assistance.

I appreciate Gen. Nordhaus’s leadership and look forward to hearing more about the Guard’s essential work in readiness, disaster response, and support missions across the country.

I was glad to meet today with Acting Commander LTC Joshua Haynes and leadership from @USACE_FortWorth to discuss their ongoing work on the Chacon Creek Project in Laredo, as well as several other Army Corps projects across our district. I applaud the House for passing the bipartisan Law Enforcement Officers Safety Reform Act. As the co-lead, I was proud to work with my colleague @RepDonBacon to address the challenges retired and off-duty officers face with concealed carry so they can keep serving our communities.

Thank you to the families, educators, and community members lifting up our youth. Laredo, the future is bright because of students like these!

At today’s House Appropriations Homeland Security Subcommittee hearing, I was pleased to speak with @Sec_Noem about commonsense, bipartisan solutions to support the brave men and women working every day to keep our southern border secure.

We discussed the need for river roads so Border Patrol agents can access remote areas safely and efficiently. I also raised concerns about Carrizo cane, which blocks visibility and hampers patrol efforts along the river.

I highlighted the urgency of updating surveillance technology, streamlining the procurement process, and deploying more AST towers. Too many areas along the border still lack coverage, putting our agents at greater risk.

I also pressed for new investments in scanning technology at our ports of entry - where most contraband comes through - and shared concerns about potential cuts to @CBP pensions that would hurt our frontline personnel.

I was especially glad to hear Secretary Noem express her interest in visiting Laredo with me to see these challenges firsthand.

South Texas knows what works on the border. I’ll keep fighting for smart, targeted investments that support our agents, protect our communities, and deliver results.

I am pleased to announce a $280 million USDA grant to provide economic relief to Rio Grande Valley farmers and producers who are suffering from Mexico’s failure to follow through on their water delivery obligations. As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I was proud to work in a bipartisan manner to secure this critical funding through the American Relief Act.

These federal dollars—secured by the House Appropriations Committee—will be distributed by the Texas Department of Agriculture and will help farmers and ranchers in South Texas recover losses from water shortages by covering costs tied to irrigated agriculture. Eligible producers with irrigation rights in 2023 or 2024 are encouraged to apply.

📍 In-person workshops to assist with applications:
Laredo – April 30 | Webb County Extension Office
San Benito – May 1 | Cameron County Annex
🕗 Both from 8:00 AM – 5:00 PM

Producers attending the workshop should bring their irrigation certificate number, documentation of water rights through TCEQ or an irrigation district, and proof of irrigable acreage. The application deadline is May 22, 2025.

For more information or to begin your application, visit the Texas Department of Agriculture’s website or contact Grants@TexasAgriculture.gov.

Remembering Bella Blue (Phantom) — 2017–2025

We honor and remember our beloved Bella Blue — affectionately known as Phantom — whose boundless love, gentle spirit, and playful heart touched every corner of our lives.

From the moment she joined our family in 2017, Bella brought a light and joy that can never be replaced. She was more than a pet; she was a faithful companion, a quiet guardian, and a constant source of comfort through every season of life. Whether bounding through the yard or greeting us with that unmistakable sparkle in her blue eyes, Bella showed us the meaning of unconditional love every single day.

It is impossible to sum up all that Bella meant to us. She was there through laughter and tears, through new beginnings and bittersweet goodbyes. Her presence made every ordinary moment something extraordinary. Bella’s spirit was kind, patient, and wise beyond words — always reminding us to find joy in the little things.

Though our hearts are heavy with grief, they are also full of gratitude. We are grateful for the countless memories, the wagging tail, the warm snuggles, and the quiet companionship she so freely gave. Bella Blue’s spirit will forever be a part of our family, living on in every smile she brought to our faces and every soft moment we now hold close.

Run free, sweet Bella. You will always be our good girl, our Phantom, and our irreplaceable friend.

Until we meet again.

Earlier, I delivered remarks at MileOne in downtown Laredo, alongside COO Cesar Hernandez, Mayor Dr. Victor Treviño, Laredo Chamber of Commerce Executive Director Monica Y. Martinez, and Councilmember Melissa Cigarroa. We discussed the critical importance of supporting small businesses in South Texas and the impact of recent federal budget cuts.

Small businesses are the backbone of our economy, but cuts to key programs, including the closure of the MBDA Rural Business Center, are making it harder for local businesses to thrive. I called for restoring vital support to help our small businesses grow and ensure a stronger future for South Texas.

This morning I held a press conference alongside Mayor Treviño to announce a major step forward for Laredo and U.S.-Mexico trade: the State Department has officially endorsed the expansion of the Colombia Solidarity International Bridge.

This isn’t just an infrastructure upgrade—it’s a vital investment in jobs, trade, and long-term economic growth. As the second-largest port in Texas after the World Trade Bridge, this crossing plays a critical role in the flow of goods between our two nations. The expansion will effectively double the amount of lanes, helping to ease congestion, improve efficiency, and support the growing volume of trade in the region.

With this project, we’re reinforcing Laredo’s role as a leader in international commerce and building a stronger, more connected future for our community and our country.

I'm committed to strengthening education and creating more opportunities for students in #TX28. In that spirit, my San Antonio Outreach Coordinator, Olivia Branson, attended the Restore Education Career Fair this week to support students as they explore future career paths.

Thank you to @restore_edu for their hard work and dedication to student success!

This week, my Starr County Outreach Coordinator Roberto Bazan joined Mayor Falcon, Chief Solis, Commissioner De Leon, and City Manager Millan to present a Congressional Certificate to Sgt. Epifanio Perez for his extraordinary heroism.

In the rushing waters of the Rio Grande, Sgt. Perez saved two lives - an act of bravery that reflects the very best of Texas.🇺🇸

It was an honor to join community leaders and volunteers to celebrate the restoration of Las Palmas Nature Trail—a powerful symbol of what we can achieve when we come together for our land, our river, and our future.

The Las Palmas Nature Trail is part of a larger effort to restore the Rio Grande’s riparian corridor—one of the most endangered in the country. Thanks to a $2 million federal earmark, we’ve already cleared 1.8 acres of invasive vegetation, including 32 tons of Carrizo Cane and Salt Cedar. In their place, we’re restoring native habitat, improving trail access, and creating a safer, more welcoming space for the community.
This work is about more than the environment—it’s about taking care of the places we share and building a stronger, more connected community.

A heartfelt thank you to Roque Haynes, Project Manager at the Zacate Creek Green District Coalition; Mariana Salinas, ZCGDC President; Tricia Cortez, Executive Director of the Rio Grande International Study Center; and Martin Castro, RGISC’s Watershed Science Director. And to the dedicated volunteers from El Azteca, ZCGDC, and RGISC—your hard work and heart for this community are what make this possible!

It was great to join @LelandVittert on @NewsNation to talk about the issues I hear about every day from South Texans: housing, reducing the cost of living, and keeping our communities safe. These are the priorities we need to stay focused on.

And while Leland and I were talking solutions, our incredible team, the @LaredosTecos - the only fully binational professional baseball team in the world - knocked out two home runs right behind me!

Last night, I had a great time at the Tecos game with my daughter Catie and was honored to throw out the first pitch of the night! It was a fantastic evening filled with energy, community spirit, and hometown pride. 

Moments like these remind me how special it is to be part of a city that values tradition, connection, and coming together to celebrate the things we love!

It's great to see Bexar County's new Precinct 4 Satellite Service Center officially open! My San Antonio Outreach Coordinator, Jesus Martinez, joined the celebration to deliver special Congressional honors marking this milestone for our #TX28 community.

This project makes life easier for residents by eliminating a 34-mile round-trip to access vital county services.

I was glad to join SKG Homes and the Laredo Chamber of Commerce to celebrate the groundbreaking of Parkway Residence—an exciting new development that reflects our shared commitment to building strong, family-friendly communities in North Laredo.

This 122-townhome project is designed with modern families in mind, offering 3- to 4-bedroom layouts, private backyards, garage parking, and a dedicated kids’ park. Its walkable layout, safety features, and close proximity to top-rated schools, shopping, and dining make it an ideal place for families to thrive.

Parkway Residence not only helps meet Laredo’s growing housing demand, but also supports our local economy by generating jobs and investing in our city’s future. I look forward to watching this vision become a reality!

It was a pleasure to celebrate the ribbon cutting of Maria E. Benavides Park alongside Mayor Dr. Victor Treviño, Council Members Ricardo Rangel Jr., Melissa Cigarroa, and Gilbert Gonzalez, and Marcela Cervantes, Assistant Director of Community Development, to celebrate the reopening of Maria E. Benavides Park—a vibrant space renewed through more than $108,000 in local and federal dollars.

Thanks to federal funding from the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program and the City’s District 2 Priority Funds, the park now features new restrooms, ADA-compliant sidewalks, A/C units, and a fully restored concession stand—meaningful upgrades that bring safety, comfort, and pride to the community.

When we invest in our neighborhoods, we’re investing in people—and today is a powerful reminder of what we can accomplish when we work together.

This morning in Laredo, I joined Mayor Dr. Victor Treviño, Community Development Director Tina Martinez, and local leaders to kick off National Community Development Week—a time to recognize the powerful impact of federal dollars in our communities through the CDBG and HOME programs.

These programs are changing lives—and I’ll keep fighting to make sure Laredo gets the support it needs to grow and thrive.

I’m honored to have received the 2025 Autism Advocacy Award, a national recognition presented during the Autism Worthy Gala Dinner hosted by the Autism Society of America—a leading organization dedicated to improving the lives of individuals and families affected by autism through advocacy, education, and support. I was proud to receive this award alongside U.S. Senator Ben Ray Luján and U.S. Senator Susan Collins.

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Autism Caucus, I’ve led bipartisan efforts to strengthen federal support for the autism community. Alongside Congressman Chris Smith, I’ve worked to advance policies that improve research, access to care, and expand services for individuals with autism across all stages of life.

A cornerstone of these efforts is the Autism CARES Act, which I helped pass and get signed into law. This important legislation directs critical funding to early diagnosis, effective interventions, workforce training, and lifelong support systems. Its continued renewal highlights the federal government’s commitment to meeting the evolving needs of the autism community.

We proudly celebrated the 25th anniversary of the World Trade Bridge—a powerful symbol of connection, commerce, and cooperation between the U.S. and Mexico.

Special thanks to Mayor Dr. Victor Treviño, Mayor Pro-Tem Vanessa Perez, Presidenta Municipal Carmen Lilia Canturosas, Elsa Hinojosa, CBP, and our private sector partners on both sides of the border. This milestone is a testament to your vision and dedication.

Laredo is the #1 port in the U.S., and with a new Presidential Permit, we’re expanding the bridge to 18 lanes—cutting wait times and boosting trade across North America.

From Texas to Monterrey and beyond, this bridge drives opportunity. As we celebrate 25 years of success, we’re not just looking back—we’re building forward!

This morning, I had the honor of speaking at a Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute briefing on Capitol Hill, where I highlighted the urgent challenges facing Colonias. These communities are close to my heart, and I am dedicated to addressing their pressing housing and infrastructure needs. 

I have worked on these needs since my earliest days in the Texas state government. I wrote and passed the landmark bill on colonias in 1995, which enabled us to regulate and improve the lives of residents. 

Now, in Congress, I have secured tens of millions of dollars for colonias’ water infrastructure, workforce support, and more. I am continuing to work to establish an office specifically for colonias in the US Department of Agriculture. 

Every American deserves a safe, dignified place where they can live and work. Together we can make that happen. 

I am grateful to the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute for giving me the platform to discuss such an important issue. I remain fully committed to advancing housing, infrastructure, and economic development in these communities. My office is always here to support and serve.

Yesterday in San Antonio, I stood with the National Association of Letter Carriers (NALC) and letter carriers from across the country as they said HELL NO to dismantling the U.S. Postal Service.

It was an honor to stand alongside Homer Hernandez, President of the NALC Alamo Branch, and other letter carriers as we showed our strong solidarity in protecting postal workers and defending this vital public service. I joined fellow Congressional representatives in voicing our firm opposition to any efforts that would threaten the future of the U.S. Postal Service—an institution protected by the Constitution of the United States.

The NALC raised important concerns about the potential privatization or dismantling of the Postal Service, and I stand with them in ensuring that doesn’t happen. The Postal Service is a lifeline for communities across this nation, and we must continue to support it, safeguard it, and ensure it remains a public service for the people. I am fully committed to standing with our postal workers and protecting the U.S. Postal Service for future generations!

Yesterday, I had the chance to visit the ROOTS Recovery Center, a facility I’m deeply proud to support. For over 530 days, 59 innocent people, including 5 Americans, have remained in captivity, and their safe return must remain a top priority. Hamas bears responsibility for this ongoing tragedy, having once again rejected opportunities to extend the ceasefire by releasing additional hostages. This afternoon, I announced $698,597 in Operation Stonegarden funding for Jim Hogg County.
These funds will assist local law enforcement with overtime pay, fuel costs, and maintenance expenses.

I helped create Operation Stonegarden in 2008. Since then, I have secured over $5 million in Stonegarden funding for Jim Hogg County.
In FY 24, I secured $81 million for the program nationally.

I am committed to ensuring that our brave law enforcement officials have the tools they need to protect our border and our community. This program is essential in funding efforts to secure the border and keep border communities safe.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will continue to bring federal resources to Jim Hogg County to help keep our community secure

Today in Starr County, I proudly announced the passage of the Social Security Fairness Act, a vital piece of legislation I co-sponsored and strongly supported. I played a key role in advancing this bill, including signing a discharge petition to bring it to a floor vote.  

This landmark legislation restores Social Security benefits for some teachers, law enforcement officers, firefighters, and postal workers—ensuring they receive the retirement benefits they have rightfully earned.  

I’m honored to have helped deliver this victory for our dedicated public servants and will continue advocating for those who work tirelessly to serve our communities here in TX-28.

I’m proud to announce $3,002,520 in federal funding for Gateway Community Health Center Inc. This investment will enhance the operations of their clinics, supporting essential services like primary care, pediatrics, women’s health, behavioral health, and more.

The funding will benefit all Gateway clinics, including the Central, South, North, Laredo College, Hebbronville, Zapata, and Mobile Clinics.
With this support, Gateway will continue serving over 34,000 patients annually, providing vital healthcare services and improving access for our community.

I’d like to thank Elmo Lopez, Chief Executive Officer, Lauro A. Garcia, Board President, and the entire board for their leadership and dedication to improving healthcare in our region. I’ll keep fighting for the healthcare resources South Texans deserve.

I previously secured $315,809 in federal funding for Lytle ISD through the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) School Violence Prevention Program (SVPP). This investment has helped strengthen school security measures, ensuring a safer learning environment for students and staff.

These funds have been used to enhance district-wide security, including bullet-resistant film for interior windows, upgraded security cameras, non-scalable fencing, advanced monitoring systems with badge access, and salaries for tech personnel to oversee and install security infrastructure. This administration's plans to reduce the federal workforce are raising concerns. While I support cutting waste and eliminating duplication, we must protect the core services that millions of Americans rely on.

The U.S. federal workforce has remained stable since 1969 and is smaller than in many other developed countries, making up just 1.87% of the civilian workforce. In contrast, nations like the UK and Canada have larger, more centralized governments.

I’m committed to ensuring our government remains efficient and accountable while safeguarding the core services that federal employees provide to the American people.

I previously secured $2,000,000 in Community Project Funding for the Rio Grande International Study Center (RGISC) and the City of Laredo to restore a segment of the Rio Grande River—Laredo’s only source of drinking water. This investment has helped address water security challenges through invasive species management and native species reforestation.

These efforts have enhanced water availability, protected riverbanks from erosion, and improved line-of-sight for U.S. Customs & Border Protection, all while preserving critical wildlife habitats. As part of the larger Binational River Park Project, this initiative has strengthened the health of the Rio Grande and ensured a sustainable water supply for our community.

I was proud to support this important work and remain committed to protecting South Texas’ most vital natural resource.

Yesterday, we marked a major win for San Antonio—a direct, nonstop flight to Washington, D.C., made possible through the bipartisan FAA Reauthorization Act. This flight strengthens our connection to the capital, benefiting our military community, business leaders, students, and families.

I previously announced $2,965,800 in Community Project Funding that I helped secure for the new Duval County Emergency Operations Center (EOC). Last year, I attended the groundbreaking for this critical facility, which will provide first responders with the resources they need to protect our community during emergencies.

Once completed, the state-of-the-art EOC will house Duval County’s fire department, first responders, and emergency services, ensuring faster response times and better coordination during disasters. It will also serve as a regional hub for law enforcement and emergency personnel, strengthening public safety across the county.

I look forward to seeing this project come to fruition and the lasting impact it will have on the safety and well-being of Duval County residents. I remain committed to securing the resources our communities need to stay prepared and protected.

Today, we broke ground on the Meals on Wheels Improvement Project in Webb County, made possible by $2.47 million in federal funding from the American Rescue Plan Act, which I proudly supported.  

This project will upgrade the facility to house the Webb County Community Action Agency’s (CAA) offices, Social Services, and a modernized Meals on Wheels kitchen. It will also add a conference room and auditorium for community training.  

These improvements will expand essential services, including meal delivery for seniors, rural transportation, housing assistance, and job training. I’m proud to support this project and the vital services it will provide to Webb County residents.

Social Security has always been a priority of mine, ensuring that every person in my district is able to put food on the table and afford their basic needs. Most recently, I helped champion the Social Security Fairness Act into law, restoring social security benefits for certain teachers, law enforcement officers, postal workers, and other critical public servants. 

I will always keep fighting to make sure that people in my district have the Social Security benefits that they’ve rightfully earned.

Last night, I was honored to accept the Outstanding Policymaker Award from Hispanics in Energy. I appreciate the work of Jose Perez, the President and CEO of Hispanics in Energy, and want to thank him, the Chairman, the Vice Chairs, and the Board of Directors for their leadership.

Last night, I was pleased to see Danielle Marasco, a local owner and operator of McDonald’s in the Laredo area, at the McDonald’s Capitol Hill Reception in DC. I was also pleased to see Congressman Kevin Hern (OK-1). It was a pleasure catching up with them and talking about the importance of supporting businesses in our areas.

I’m excited to announce that the Social Security Administration is starting to pay retroactive benefits and increase monthly payments for individuals affected by the Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) and Government Pension Offset (GPO), thanks to the Social Security Fairness Act, which I helped champion.

Supporting teachers, law enforcement, postal workers, and public servants has always been a priority. By co-sponsoring and passing this legislation, I’m ensuring they get the benefits they’ve earned.

Most recipients will receive their retroactive payment by the end of March, with increased benefits starting in April. Social Security will send notices explaining these changes, and beneficiaries are encouraged to wait until April to inquire about their payments.

For more details and updates, visit the Social Security Fairness Act webpage.

Supporting students’ mental health is essential to their well-being and success. That’s why last year, I announced $2,690,608 in federal funding that I helped secure to expand mental health services in the San Antonio Independent School District (SAISD). As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I secured this funding through the Department of Education’s Mental Health Service Professional Demonstration Grant to help train and grow SAISD’s mental health workforce.

This funding is supporting Con Cariño: School Mental Health with Heart, a five-year initiative that provides hands-on experience, covers licensing exam costs, and creates a pathway to full-time employment for social work and counseling interns. By strengthening SAISD’s mental health services, this program is ensuring more students receive the support they need. I remain committed to securing federal funding to expand critical mental health resources for our schools.

Earlier today, I hosted my weekly press conference, Conversation with Cuellar, where we discussed updates on the Farm Bill and the urgent need for its bipartisan passage.  

I was joined by Texas Farm Bureau President Russell Boening, Regan Beck, Director of Government Affairs, and Laramie Adams, Associate Government Affairs Director, to highlight the bill’s importance and its impact on farmers, ranchers, and rural communities. It was a productive discussion, and I appreciate everyone who took the time to join us.

Today, I visited the Ruthe B. Cowl Rehabilitation Center and had the opportunity to see the incredible work they do to support patients on their road to recovery. RBC focuses on improving mobility, balance, and independence while helping patients recover from illness or injury.

This afternoon in Zapata County, I had the privilege of announcing the passage of the Social Security Fairness Act, an essential bill that I was proud to co-sponsor and strongly advocate for. I played a critical role in pushing this legislation forward, including signing a discharge petition to ensure it reached the House floor for a vote.  

This groundbreaking legislation reinstates Social Security benefits for some teachers, law enforcement officers, firefighters, and postal workers—ensuring they receive the retirement support they have earned through their service.  

After the announcement, I toured the Zapata County Jail with Zapata County Judge Joseph Rathmell and Zapata County Sheriff Ramon Montes. I appreciate their dedication to public safety and look forward to supporting them however I can.

It’s an honor to have played a part in achieving this important win for our dedicated public servants, and I will continue working to protect those who selflessly serve the people of TX-28. To learn more about the Social Security Fairness Act, I encourage you to explore the fact sheet linked here, which offers detailed and helpful information.

Happy Presidents’ Day!  

Today, we honor the leadership and legacy of those who have served as President of the United States, guiding our nation through challenges and triumphs. As we observe this day, let us reflect on the principles of democracy, unity, and progress that define our country.  

May God bless our nation’s leaders—past, present, and future—and may He continue to bless and protect the United States of America.

This afternoon, Imelda and I attended the 127th Washington’s Birthday Celebration Association (WBCA) Stars & Stripes Air Show Spectacular, sponsored by Miller Lite, at the Laredo International Airport. This exciting event brought the community together for a day of breathtaking aerial performances, dynamic displays, and family-friendly entertainment. It was a fantastic opportunity to experience the thrill of aviation, enjoy special guest appearances, and take part in interactive exhibits. The air show remains a cherished tradition of the WBCA festivities, and we were delighted to share in the excitement with everyone in attendance!

Last night, Imelda and I attended the 45th annual Princess Pocahontas Pageant at the Lilia Martinez Fine Arts Center Theater. This cherished tradition honors Native American culture and respect for nature. Congratulations to Briseis Alexandra Sauceda, this year’s Princess Pocahontas, and Jeremy Rodriguez, Chief Blue Eagle. It was a wonderful evening celebrating history, tradition, and community.

Last night, my wife, Imelda, and I attended the Instituto Cultural Mexicano de Laredo’s “Noche de Gala” at the Falcon Bank Ballroom. During the event, I presented a Congressional Certificate of Recognition to Francisco “Pancho” Ochoa, founder of El Pollo Loco, Palenque Grill, and Taco Palenque. It was a wonderful evening celebrating culture, entrepreneurship, and community, and I truly enjoyed sharing it with everyone in attendance.

Last year, I announced $1,000,000 in Community Project Funding that I helped secure for the construction of the Zapata County Emergency Operations Center (EOC). It is essential that our first responders have the proper facilities and accommodations to respond effectively in a crisis. This new state-of-the-art, centralized facility will provide Zapata County’s first responders, fire department, and emergency services with the resources they need to enhance coordination and improve emergency response times for local residents.

With nearly 15,000 residents relying on these critical services, the new EOC will enhance emergency response times and elevate the quality of service across the community. I look forward to its completion and the lasting impact it will have on Zapata County’s emergency preparedness and public safety. As a senior member of the Appropriations Committee, I remain committed to securing vital funding to support our first responders and ensure they have the resources needed to protect our communities.

Happy Valentine’s Day from my family to yours!  

I’m blessed for my amazing wife, Imelda, and our beautiful daughters, Catie and Christina. Thank you, Imelda, for your love, for our family, and for the joy you bring into our lives. https://t.co/402NCWcHi9

Today in Washington, DC, I introduced the Land Port of Entry (LPOE) Modernization Trust Fund Act for the 119th Congress.

This vital legislation will establish a trust fund to construct new ports of entry, expand and improve existing ones, procure technology for inspecting and processing traffic, and hire additional U.S. Customs and Border Protection staff.

Strengthening our ports of entry is essential to enhancing security, facilitating trade, and improving efficiency along our southern border.

I want to thank @RepTonyGonzales, @RepEscobar, @RepGonzalez, and @RepGabeVasquez for supporting this legislation as original co-sponsors. I am proud to champion this bipartisan initiative and remain committed to serving the communities of TX-28.

I am proud to have secured $2,000,000 in federal funding for Webb County’s Veterans Treatment Program (VTP), which I announced last year. Provided over a five-year period, this funding is expanding the Veterans Treatment Court Program to help veterans overcome substance abuse and mental health challenges through treatment, education, and rehabilitation services.

It also extends support to veterans in five neighboring rural counties—Zapata, Jim Hogg, Starr, Duval, and Jim Wells—where a lack of resources has left many without critical care. By reducing recidivism, improving mental health, and promoting public safety, this program is helping veterans build better lives.

Thank you to all the veterans in South Texas and across the nation for your service. I remain committed to ensuring you receive the care and support you deserve.

This morning I joined Elizabeth Alonzo-Villarreal, CEO of NeighborWorks Laredo, to announce their official certification as a Community Development Financial Institution (CDFI).  

This certification expands access to federal funding, allowing NeighborWorks Laredo to enhance its services for underserved families. As a CDFI, they can now apply for new federal resources, strengthen partnerships, and provide more support for homeownership and financial stability in our community.  

I have long supported NeighborWorks Laredo’s mission and remain committed to securing resources for affordable housing in South Texas. I thank Elizabeth Alonzo-Villarreal and the entire team at NeighborWorks Laredo for their dedication, and I look forward to continuing our work to strengthen our community!

This afternoon in Laredo, I announced $20 million in federal funding for critical water infrastructure—funding I helped secure through the latest government funding bill.  

The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has officially posted the $20 million funding breakdown to initiate and complete the design and construction of the water supply infrastructure improvement project. The Army Corps is also working with my office and the City of Laredo on the next steps of the project. I thank the House Appropriations Committee, bipartisan leadership, the Laredo City Council, City Managers, and Mayor Victor Treviño for their partnership.  

This investment builds on the $35 million I helped secure to overhaul the Jefferson Water Treatment Plant, strengthening Laredo’s water infrastructure for generations to come. I will continue fighting for the resources our communities need to grow and thrive.

Today, I was pleased to announce that I successfully secured $20 million in federal funding and support for water infrastructure in Laredo. I have long fought to make sure that my district has access to safe, reliable water, including 10 years ago, when I secured $35 million for the Jefferson Water Treatment Plant.
