Historic news – Today I announced that the Social Security Fairness Act of 2023 has passed both the House and Senate and is heading to the President's desk!

This bill, which I championed, removes provisions that reduce Social Security benefits for teachers, law enforcement officers, firefighters, postal workers, and other critical public servants across my district.

I am happy to support our public servants in South Texas by passing legislation that ensures they get the benefits they’ve rightfully earned. That is why over the years I’ve worked across the aisle to restore full social security benefits for our workers.

Today, I was pleased to honor Texas State Representative Tracy O. King for his dedication and service to the State of Texas. He continues to advocate strongly for health, agriculture, and resource management issues and has made great contributions to the well-being of Texas communities. He is a true model for integrity and leadership.

Today, I recognized Laredo Assistant Manager Steve Landin for his 30-year career with the City of Laredo, including being one of only 22 people in American history to serve as both Police Chief and Fire Chief in their community. He has made extraordinary contributions to South Texas, and his legacy in public safety, administration, and service will continue to be felt.

We got it done.

Today, I was happy to pass the bipartisan government funding bill that will keep our government open through March 14th.

In this legislation, I helped secure $10 billion in economic assistance as well as $21 billion in disaster assistance for our farmers and ranchers.

Furthermore, I helped secure language to provide economic support to farmers who have been negatively impacted by Mexico's failure to deliver water to the United States in accordance with the 1944 Water Treaty.

I also secured critical funding for water infrastructure projects in the district.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will continue to provide the resources South Texans need to prosper.

Great news – the 2025 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) passed the House floor and is headed to the Senate!

I’m pleased to announce the new Customs Trade Partnership Against Terrorism (CTPAT) Field Office at the World Trade Bridge in Laredo. This initiative enhances trade security and supports local economies, and I’m glad to have secured funding for its establishment.

A special thanks to CBP headquarters, U.S. customs brokers, and the local CBP team for their crucial support in making this project a reality. Together, we are strengthening trade security and fostering economic growth in our community.

I’m excited to announce the opening of the new Customs Trade Partnership Against Terrorism (CTPAT) Field Office at the World Trade Bridge in Laredo. I secured funding for this office as part of my commitment to support Customs and Border Protection (CBP) operations.
 
The CTPAT program is essential for enhancing international supply chain security while facilitating the movement of legitimate, low-risk cargo. This office will handle program applications, assess eligibility, certify new members, and maintain ongoing accounts, covering Laredo and cross-border cities in Tamaulipas, Mexico.
 
This office is a crucial step in strengthening trade security and promoting economic growth in our community. I want to extend my thanks to JD Gonzalez, President of NCBFAA, and the Laredo trade community for their leadership and support in making this project a reality. 

I’m dedicated to ensuring we have the resources necessary to enhance border security and support local economies.

The U.S. economy grew by 2.8% from July to September, driven by strong consumer spending despite high interest rates. This is a slight decline from 3% in the previous quarter but indicates stability ahead.

Consumer spending rose 3.7%, and exports increased 8.9%, though business investment in housing slowed.

Inflation eased to just 1.5%, the lowest in over four years. With interest rates beginning to fall, consumer confidence is improving, raising optimism for future growth.

Today, I announced $11,077,810 in federal funding for Opportunity Home San Antonio. 

This funding is critical in combating health hazards in public households in San Antonio and represents an important investment in the health and long-term success of our community. 

I want to extend my gratitude to Opportunity Home Chairman of the Board Gabriel Lopez, Acting President and CEO Michael Reyes, Government Relations Advisor Hector Morales, and State Representative Josey Garcia for their commitment to creating a healthier community.
 
This funding comes from the Department of Housing and Urban Development’s Capital Fund Housing-Related Hazards and Lead-Based Paint Capital Fund Programs. These programs focus on evaluating and eliminating residential health hazards, including lead-based paint, carbon monoxide, mold, radon, and fire safety risks.
 
I remain dedicated to advocating for the necessary funding and resources to ensure our region becomes a healthier and more prosperous community for all.

Today, I announced $186,293 in federal funding for McMullen County through Operation Stonegarden.

This funding will enhance local law enforcement efforts by supporting the McMullen County Sheriff’s Office. It will be used for overtime pay, fuel costs, and new equipment—resources essential for ensuring the safety of our community and retaining our officers.

Since I helped create Operation Stonegarden in 2008, it has been instrumental in securing our southern border. To date, over $1.2 million has been allocated to McMullen County, reflecting our ongoing commitment to local law enforcement.

I am proud to advocate for the resources our law enforcement needs to keep our communities safe.

I announced $270 million in federal funding for the VIA Metropolitan Transit’s Advanced Rapid Transit Green Line project and nearly $1.7 million for the Brooks Development Authority.

This funding will significantly improve transportation for San Antonio residents, particularly in underserved areas, enhancing access to education and jobs. I extend my gratitude to VIA leadership, the Brooks Development Board, and our local representatives for their partnership and support. This achievement reflects a collaborative effort among all of us involved.

The Green Line will include dedicated lanes, off-board fare collection, and transit-priority traffic signals to reduce travel times. Of the total funding, $158 million comes from the FY23 Appropriations Bill, with an additional $110 million earmarked for the 2025 budget.

Additionally, the Brooks Development funding will support the installation of 24 publicly accessible EV charging stations at Brooks City Base, improving accessibility for local residents.

I remain committed to advocating for essential infrastructure funding that enhances our communities’ quality of life.

Today, I announced $2,690,608 in federal funding to enhance mental health support for the San Antonio Independent School District (SAISD). 

This funding, from the Department of Education’s Mental Health Service Professional Demonstration Grant, will support the Con Cariño initiative, improving the internship-to-employment pipeline for licensed Master Social Workers.

The grant will place four social work interns and two school psychology interns in the district, addressing the need for more licensed mental health professionals. Local graduate students will gain hands-on experience while receiving compensation and support for licensing exam costs, helping to retain staff who understand community needs.

I have previously secured funding for SAISD, including resources for school lunch reimbursements. I will continue to advocate for federal support to expand mental health services for our students.

It was a pleasure to attend the Border Patrol Youth of the Month ceremony, a program dedicated to honoring and promoting academic excellence among high school students in our area. 

I have been working with Border Patrol on Youth of the Month since I was a state rep, helping to create the Youth of the Year program during that time. 

It’s inspiring to see young leaders recognized for their hard work and dedication. Here’s to their continued success and the positive impact they will make in our communities!

Today, I celebrated the ribbon-cutting of the new Gateway Community Health Center-West Clinic in Laredo, the first clinic on the west side of the city, made possible by $2,000,000 in federal funding.

Gateway is essential to our health system, and this clinic will provide Laredo residents with the quality care they need. I want to thank Elmo Lopez, Lauro Garcia, City Councilwoman Alyssa Cigarroa, Mayor Dr. Victor Trevino, and the entire Gateway staff for their dedication.

I announced $260,700 in federal funding for Texas A&M International University (TAMIU) research. 

This funding will allow TAMIU faculty to purchase a Self-Driving Car Studio Bundle, a complete lab for researching self-driving vehicle technology.

Students will develop algorithms prioritizing metrics like delay and emissions, while also studying resilience and fault tolerance. The lab will provide hands-on opportunities for students across engineering programs and engage at least 100 local middle and high school students in STEM fields.

This initiative will empower students to lead in emerging technologies and ensure that our community plays a vital role in shaping the future of transportation and engineering.

Today, I participated in a panel discussion hosted by the Laredo Chamber of Commerce on the Colombia Bridge expansion project and its impact on international trade.

I’m pleased to have collaborated with Senator Cruz and Senator Cornyn to include language in the FY24 National Defense Authorization Act to expedite the Presidential permit for this project. Expanding the bridge from 8 lanes to 16 will enhance our supply chain, reduce congestion, and drive economic growth.

Alongside Mayor Victor Trevino, Senator Cruz, and Governor Samuel Garcia, we highlighted the importance of this expansion and its role in facilitating trade between the U.S. and Mexico.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Committee, I remain dedicated to reforming the permitting process and strengthening our cross-border connections to support our communities.

Today, I celebrated the ribbon-cutting ceremony for the Rio Grande City Public Safety Building, made possible by $2.5 million in federal funding. 

This facility will provide critical support to our local law enforcement and fire department, enhancing public safety for the community.

This project will be used to install new equipment, provide furnishings, and 13 new vehicles. This investment highlights my dedication to equipping our first responders with the necessary resources to effectively serve and protect the community.

I want to thank Rio Grande City Mayor Gilberto Falcon, the City Council, City Manager Gilberto Milan, RGC Fire Chief Manuel Muniz, RGC Police Chief Noe Castillo, and former Mayor Joel Villarreal, along with former City Commissioners Alberto Escobedo and Rey Ramirez, for their leadership in bringing this project to fruition.

I attended the groundbreaking of the $285 million Joint Processing Center in Laredo, TX, and hosted a press conference afterward.

As a senior member of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security, I secured funding for this facility, which will enhance collaboration among Customs and Border Protection (CBP), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and other DHS agencies like Homeland Security Investigations (HSI).

This center will address irregular migration, reduce costs, and allow CBP to demobilize the temporary soft-sided facility. Owned by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), this project will also bolster border security and create local jobs.

This groundbreaking represents another major investment in homeland security, solidifying Laredo as a key center for the Department of Homeland Security operations and enhancing safety in our region.

Today, I celebrated the Starr-Camargo Bridge Expansion Act in Rio Grande City.

In 2023, Mexico was the top U.S. trading partner, with $798.8 billion in trade. The Starr-Camargo Bridge is crucial for this trade, facilitating hundreds of millions of dollars and connecting South Texas to Mexico. 

This expansion will reduce congestion and truck idling at the port of entry, helping to address supply chain issues.

I worked closely with Senators Cornyn and Cruz, whose leadership helped pass this important legislation. I also want to thank Mayor Falcon for his contributions and the Starr-Camargo Bridge Company President Sam Vale and Chief Operating Officer Robert A. Vale for hosting this celebration. 

This expansion is significant step forward for our region and economy.

The Federal Trade Commission has introduced a "click to cancel" rule, requiring businesses to make subscription cancellations as easy as sign-ups.

This addresses consumer complaints about difficult cancellation processes and hidden subscriptions. Companies must simplify the procedure.

This initiative is part of the Biden administration’s efforts to combat junk fees and improve transparency, with new requirements taking effect in about six months to enhance the FTC’s ability to help consumers obtain refunds from non-compliant companies.

The goal is to create a fairer marketplace.

This week, I announced $100,000 in federal funding for green energy research at TAMIU. 

The funding comes from the Department of Energy's Office of Fossil Energy and Carbon Management (FECM). Awarded as part of the Capacity Building for Repurposing Energy Assets Initiative, this funding will help communities like ours repurpose energy infrastructure and transition to clean energy solutions.  

Together, we are laying the groundwork for a more sustainable, prosperous future -- one that builds on Texas' legacy while looking forward to the opportunities that clean energy offers.
